editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.resp: Incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words were reviewed and in many cases fixed by
respStmt.name: Madeline Burg

respStmt.resp: Tokenization and linguistic annotation using MorphAdorner and NUPOS 2.0 were provided by
respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: A provisional, rudimentry, and algorithmically produced castlist was added as a new div in the back listing each role with their number of speeches sorted from high to low by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: Project co-ordination and review of textual changes and linguistic annotation by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

div.p: With new additions of Mr. Chaughs and Trimtrams roaring, and the bawd's song. Never before printed.
As it was acted before the King, by the prince his highness' servants.
Written by Thomas Midleton, and William Rowley. gent.
Printed at London for I. T. and are to be sold at Christ church gate. 1617.

div.head: To the nobly disposed, virtuous, and faithful-breasted Robert grey esquire, one of the grooms of his highness' bedchamber, his poor well-willer, wisheth his best wishes. Hic es supra.

body.p:
'Tis but a play, and a play is but a butt, against which many shoot many arrows of envy, 'tis the weaker part, and how much more noble shall it be in you to defend it, yet if it be (As some philosophers have left behind 'em) that this megacosm, this great world, is no more than a stage, where every one must act his part, you shall of necessity have many partakers, some long, some short, some indifferent, all some, whilst indeed the players themselves have
the least part of it, for I know few that have lands, (Which are a part of the world) and therefore no grounded men, but howsoever they serve for mutes, happily they must wear good clothes for attendance, yet all have exits and must all be stripped in the tiring-house (Viz, the grave) for none must carry anything out of the stock, you see sir, I write as I speak, and I speak as I am, and that's excuse enough for me. I did not mean to write an epistle of praise to you, it looks so like a thing, (I know) you love not flattery, which you exceedingly Hate actively, and unpleasingly accept passively: indeed I meant to tell you your own, that is, that this child of the muses is yours, whoever begat it, 'tis laid to your charge and (For ought I know) you must father and keep it too, if it please you, I hope you shall not be ashamed of it neither for it has been seen (Though I say it) in good companies, and many have said it is a handsome pretty spoken infant, now be your own judge, at your leisure look on it, at your pleasure laugh at it, and if you be sorry it is no better you may be glad it is no bigger.

div.head: Actus primus, scaena prima.

sp.speaker: Russell:

lg.l: It must be all my ear; there's all my love,
And that pulls on the tother, had I been left
In a son behind me, while I had been here
He should have shifted as I did before him;
Lived on the freeborn portion of his wit:
But a daughter, and that an only one, o ▪
We cannot be too careful or, too tender,
'Tis such a brittle niceness: a mere cupboard of glasses,
The least shake breaks, or cracks 'em; all my aim is
To cast her upon riches: that's the thing
We richmen call perfection, for the world
Can perfect naught without it, 'tis not neatness
Either in handsome wit; or handsome outside
With which one gentleman (Far indebt) has courted her
Which boldness he shall rue. He thinks me blind,
And ignorant, I have let him play a long time,
Seemed to believe his worth; which I know nothing.
He may perhaps laugh at my easy confidence
Which closely I requite upon his fondness.
For this hour, snaps him; and before his mistress
His saint forsooth, which he inscribes my girl,
He shall be rudely taken and disgraced,
The trick will prove an everlasting scarecrow,
To fright poor gallants from our rich-men's daughters,

sp.stage: Enter the lady Ager, with two servants.

lg.l: Sister? I've such a joy to make you a welcome of,
Better you never tasted.

sp.speaker: Russ.
sp.l: Colonels come, and your son captain Ager;

lg.l: I know your eye would be first served,
That's the soul's taster still for grief, or joy,
O if a mother's dear suit may prevail with him,
From England; he shall never part again,

sp.speaker: Russ.
sp.l: No question he'll be ruled, and grant you that,

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: I'll bring all my desires to that request.

lg.l: Affectionate sister, she has no daughter now
It follows all the love must come to him,
And he has a worth deserves it, were it dearer.

div.stage: Enter a friend of the colonels, and another of captain Ager's.

sp.speaker: Colonel Frien.
sp.l: I must not give way to't,

sp.speaker: Colonel Frie.
sp.l: Compare young captain Ager, with the colonel,

lg.l: Young? why, do you make youth stand for an imputation: that which you now produce for his disgrace,
Infers his nobleness, that being young
Should have an anger more inclined to courage
And moderation then the colonel:
A virtue as rare as chastity in youth.
And let the cause be good; (Conscience in him
Which ever crowns his acts, and is indeed,
Valour's prosperity) he dares then as much,
As ever mad him famous that you plead for;

sp.speaker: Russ.
sp.p: Here's noble youths, belike some wench has cross 'em, and now they know not what to do with their blood.

div.stage: Enter the colonel and captain Agar.

sp.speaker: Colonel
sp.l: So serious at your game, come, come, the quarrel,

sp.speaker: Colonel friendship
sp.l: Bleed, where, pish, a little scratch by chance sir,

lg.l: What need this niceness, when you know so well
That I must know these things, and truly know 'em,
Your daintiness makes me but more impatient,
This strange concealment frets me.
Words did pass
Which I was bound to answer, as my opinion
And love instructed me, and should I take in general fame,
Into 'em, I think I should commit no error in't,

sp.speaker: Colonel
sp.l: What words sir, and of whom,

lg.l: This gentleman.
Paralleled captain Ager's worth with yours,
It was a thing I could nor listen to
With any patience.
What should ail you sir,
There was little wrong done to your friend i'that,
I said so, friend.
And I suppose that you'll esteem it so;
Why this? twixt friend, and friend,
There is so even and level a degree
It will admit of no superlative.
Good sir give me leave, in terms of manhood?
What can you dispute more questionable ▪
You are a captain sir, I give you all your due,
And you are a colonel, a title
Which may include within it many captains,
Yet sir, but throwing by those titular shadows,
Which add ne substance to the men themselves;
And take them uncompounded, man and man;
They may be so with fair equality,
And you have a beard sir.
Virginity and marriage are both worthy,
And the positive purity there are some
have made the nobler.
I shrink not, he that goes the foremost,
May be o'ertaken.
In an even balance sir, a beard put in
Gives but a small advantage: man and man
And lift the scales,
Patience shall be my curse
If it tide me further;
How now gallants?
Believe me then, I must give aim no longer,
Can words beget swords and bring 'em forth, ha?
Come they are abortive propagations;
Hide they for shame, I had thought soldiers
Had been musical; would not strike out of time,
But to the consort of drum, trumps and fife.
'Tis madman-like to dance without music.
And most unpleasing shows to the beholders,
A Lydian ditty to a Doric note
Friends embrace with steel hands? fie, it meets too hard,
I must have those encounters here debarred,
Shall I lose here what I have safe brought home
Through many dangers?
My fame,
Life of the life, my reputation,
Death? I am squared and measured out, my heights
Depths, breadth, all my dimensions taken,
Sure I have yet beyond your astrolabe
A spirit unbounded;
Tush, all this is weighing fire, vain and fruitless,
The further it runs into argument
The further plunged, beseech you no more on't,
I have a little claim, sir, in your blood
As near as the brother to your mother,
If that may serve for power to move your quiet
The rest I shall make up with courtesy
and an uncle's love.

sp.speaker: Russ.
sp.l: But! I'll have no more shooting at these butts,

sp.speaker: Colonel
sp.l: We'll to pricks, when he please,

lg.l: You rove all still
Sir, I have no motive proof to digest
Your raisd choler back into temperate blood,
But if you'll make mine age a counsellor
(As all ages have hitherto allowed it)
Wisdom in men grows up as years increase,
You shall make me blessed in making peace,
And do your judgement right,
In peace at home
Grey hairs are senators: but to determine
Soldiers and their actions;
'Tis peace here sir,
And see, here comes a happy interim,
Here enters now a scene of loving arms;
This couple will not quarrel so;
Be advised sir,
This gentleman Fitzallen is your kinsman,
You may o'erthrow his long laboured fortunes
With one angry minute, 'tis a rich churl
And this his sole inheritrix, blast not
His hopes with this tempest,
It shall calm me,
All the town's conjurers and their daemons
Could not have laid my spirit so,
Worthy coz
I gratulate your fair return to peace
Your swift fame was at home long before you;
It meets (I hope) your happy fortunes here
And I am glad in't, I must salute your joys, coz,
With a soulder's encounterKisses her.
Worthy captain Ager,
I hope my kinsman shortly, —
You must come short indeed,
or the length of my device will be ill shrunk,
Why now it shows finely, I'll tell you, sir,
Sir, nay son, I know i'th end, 'twill be so,
Hope? nay 'tis past all hope, son,
Here has been such a stormy encounter,
Betwixt my cousin captain and this brave colonel
About I know not what, nothing indeed,
Competitions, degrees and comparatives
Of soldiership: but this smooth passage
Of love has calmed it all, come I'll have't found,
Let me see your hearts combined in your hands,
And then I will believe the league is good,
It shall be the grapes if we drink any blood.
I have had none,
My blood has not yet rose to a quarrel,
Nor have you had cause,
No cause of quarrel?
Death? if my father should tell me so:
Faith, I have done, coz,
You do too hastily believe mine anger,
And yet to say, deminiting valour
In a soldier is no cause of quarrel.
Nay then I'll remove the cause to kill th'effect,
Kinsman, I'll press you to't, if either love
Or consanguinity may move you to't,
I must disarm you, though year a soldier,
Pray grant me your weapon, it shall be safe
At your regress from my house, now I know
No words can move this noble soldiers sword
To a man undefenced so, we shall parley,
And safely make all perfect friends again,
To show my will sir, accept mine to you,
As good not wear it as not dare to use it.
Nay then sir, we will be all exampled.
We'll have no arms here now but lovers arms.
No seconds must begin a quarrel,
Take mine sir.
Why la, what a fine sun shines here? these
Clouds my breath has blown into another climate,
I'll be your armourers, they are not pawned,
These were the fish that I did angle for,
I have caught 'em finely, now for my trick,
My project's lusty, and will hit the nick. Exit with weapons.
What is't a match beauty? I would now have,
Alliance with my worthy captain Ager,
To knit our loves the faster; here's witness
Enough if you confirm it now.
Sir my voice,
Was long since given, since that I gave my hand,
That wish comes too late,
For I too soon fear my delivery:(Aside.)
My father's hand sticks yet sir, you may now
Challenge a lawful interest in his,
He took your hand from your enraged blood,
And gave it freely to your opposite
My cousin Ager, methinks you should claim from him,
In the less quality of calmer blood,
To join the hands of two divided friends,
Even these two that would offer willingly
Their own embrace.
Troth, she instructs you well
Colonel: and you shall do a lover's part
Worth one brave act of valour.
Why, I did
Misdoubt no scruple, is there doubt in it?
Faith sir, delays, which at the least are doubts,
But here's a constant resolution fixed,
Which we wish willingly he would accord to,
Tush he shall do't, I will not be denied,
He owes me so much in the recompense
Of my reconcilement, captain Ager
You will take our parts against your uncle
in this quarrel?
I shall do my best, sir,
Two denials shall not repulse me, I love
Your worthy kinsman and wish him mine, I know
He doubts it not.
Your cue.
Be sure you keep it, 'twill be spoken quickly.
Therefore watch it.

sp.speaker: Colonel
sp.l: Let's set on him all at once.

sp.speaker: Omnes,
sp.l: Sir, we have a suit to you.

lg.l: On speaker may yet deliver, say, say,
I shall not dare to stand out against so many,
Faith sir here's a brabbling matter hangs on demur,
I make the motion for all, without a fee
Pray you let it be ended this term,
Ha, ha, ha.
That's the rascals cue, and he has missed it. aside .
What is it? what is it sir?
Why sir, here's a man;
And here's a woman; you're scholar good enough,
Put 'Am together; and tell me what it spells,

sp.speaker: Russ.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha, there's his cue once again,

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: My master laughs, that's his cue to mischief,

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Sir, there's a couple desire speedily to speak with you.

sp.speaker: Russ.
sp.l: A couple sir, of what, hounds, or horses?

lg.l: Men sir, gentlemen or yeomen, I know not which;
But the one sure they are

sp.speaker: Russ.
sp.l: Hast thou no other description of them.

lg.l: They come with commission, they say, sir to
Taste of your earth: if they like it, they'll turn it into gunpowder.
O, they are salt-peetermen, before me
And they bring commission: the King's power indeed,
they must have entrance, but the knaves will be bribed,
There's all the hope we have in officers,
They were too dangerous in a common wealth,
But that they will be very, well corrupted, necessary varlets,
By all fair means sir.
And with all speed sir give 'em very good words,
To save my ground unravished, unbroke up,
Mines yet a virgin earth: the worm hath not been seen,
To wriggle in her chaste bowels: and I'd be loath
A gunpowder fellow should deflower her now.

sp.speaker: Colonel
sp.l: Our suit is yet delayed by this means sir,

lg.l: Alas I cannot help it, these fellows gone
(As I hope I shall dispatch 'em quickly)
A few articles shall conclude your suit,
Who? Mr. Fitzallen: the only man
That my adoption aims at.

sp.speaker: Russ.
sp.l: You are welcome sir for ought I know yet,

sp.speaker: 2. Servant
sp.l: We come to take a view and taste of your ground, sir,

lg.l: I had rather feed you with better meat, gentlemen,
But do your pleasures, pray:

sp.l: This is our pleasures, we arrest you, sir, in the King's name

sp.speaker: Colonel
sp.l: Our weapons, good sir furnish us.

lg.l: Stay stay, gentlemen, let's inquire the cause,
It may be but a trifle; a small debt,
Shall need no rescue here.

sp.p: Sir betwixt three creditors: Mr. Leach, mr.. Swallow, and mr. Bonesuck, the debts are a thousand pounds.

lg.l: A thousand pounds?
Beshrew me a good man's substance.

sp.speaker: Colonel
sp.p: Good sir our weapons we'll teach these varlets to walk in their own particoloured coats, that they may be distinguished from honest men.

lg.l: Sir, attempt no rescue, he's our prisoner,
You'll make the danger worse by violence.
A plague upon your gunpowder treason;
Ye quick damned varlets, is this your salt peter proving,
Your tasting earth, would you might never feed better,
Nor none of your catchpole tribe:
Our weapons good sir, we'll yet deliver him.
Pardon me sir,
I dare not suffer rescue here,
At least not by so great an accessary
As to furnish you; had you had your weapons,
But to see the ill fate on't, my fine trick i'faith,
Let beggars beware to love rich-men's daughters,
I'll teach they the new morris, I learned it
Myself of another careful father.
I ith' field,
But not in the city, sir, if this gentleman
Will be one, we'll easily admit the second.
Who I? sir, pray pardon me, I am wronged,
Very much wronged in this, I must needs speak it,
Sir, you have not dealt like an honest lover,
With me nor my child, here you boast to me
Of a great revenue, a large substance
Wherein you would endow and state my daughter,
Had I missed this, my opinion yet
Thought you a frugal man, to understand,
The sure wards against all necessities,
Boldly to defend your wife and family,
To walk unmuffled, dreadless of these flesh-hooks,
Even in the daring'st streets through all the city,
But now I find you a loose prodigal,
A large unthrift, a whole thousand pound?
Come from him girl, his inside is not found?
Sir I am wronged,
These are malicious plots,
Of some obscure enemies that I have,
These debts are none of mine.
I all say so,
perhaps you stand engaged for other men,
If so you do, you must then cal't your own,
The like arrearage do I run into
Should I battle you; but I have vowed against it,
And I will keep my vows: that's religious.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: All this is nothing so sir.

lg.l: Nothing so?
By my faith it is sir, my vows are firm,
I neither owe these debts,
Nor engaged for others.
The easier is your liberty regained,
These appear proofs to me,
Liberty sir?
I hope you'll not see him go to prison,
I do not mean to bear him company
So far: but I'll see him out of my doors,
O sir, let him go to prison, 'tis a school
To tame wild bloods, he'll be much better fort,
In prison,
Believe it many an honest man lies in prison,
Else all the keepers are knaves,
They told me so themselves.
Sir, I do now suspect you have betrayed him,
And us to cause us to be weaponless,
If it be so you're a blood sucking churl,
One that was born in a great frost, when charity
Could not stir a finger, and you shall die
In heat of a burning fever i'th dog ▪ days,
To begin your hell to you, I have said your grace for you,
Now get you to supper as soon as you can,
Pluto the master of the house is set already,

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Sir you do wrong mine uncle.

lg.l: Pox on your uncle,
And all his kin, if my kinsman mingle
No blood with him.

sp.speaker: Colonel
sp.l: Foul mouthed I will be, thou'rt the son of a whore,

lg.l: Ha! whore! plagues and furies I'll thrust that back,
Or pluck thy heart out after, son of a whore?

sp.speaker: Colonel
sp.l: On thy life I'll prove it,

lg.l: Death I am naked,
Uncle, I'll give you my left hand, for my sword,
To arm my right with; o this fire will flame me
Into present ashes,
Sir, give us weapons,
We ask our own, you will not rob us of them?
No sir, but still restrain your furies here,
At my door I'll give you them, nor, at this time
My nephews, a time will better suit you,
And I must tell you sir, you have spoke swords,
And 'gainst the law of arms poisoned the blades
And with them wounded the reputation
Of an unblemished woman: would you 'Were out of my doors.
Pox on your doors, and let it run all your house o'er,
Give me my sword.
Yes better provided, to spur thee more,
I do repeat my words son of a whore. Exit with his friend.
Come sir, 'tis no worse than 'twas:
You can do nothing now. Exit Capt. and his friend.

sp.speaker: Russ.
sp.l: No, I'll bar him now, away with that beggar,Exit.

lg.l: Good sir, let this persuade you for two minutes stay,
At this prize (I know) you can wait all day.

sp.speaker: 1. Servant
sp.l: You know the remora that stays our ship always.

lg.l: Your ship sinks many when this hold let's go,
O my Fitzallen what is to be done,
To be still thine is all my part to be,
Whether in freedom or captivity,

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.l: But art thou so engaged as this pretends?

lg.l: By heaven, sweet Jane 'tis all a hellish plot
Your cruel smiling father all this while,
Has candied o'er a bitter pill for me,
Thinking by my remove to plant some other,
And then let go his fangs.
Plant some other?
Thou hast too firmly stamped me for thine own,
Ever to be razed out, I am not currant
In any others hand; I fear too soon
I shall discover it.
Let come the worst,
Bind but this knot with an unloosed line,
I will be still thine own ..

sp.speaker: 1. Servant
sp.l: My watch has gone two minutes m.

sp.speaker: Fitz
sp.l: It shall not be renewed, I go sir, farewell.

lg.l: Farewell, we both are prisoned, though not together:
But here's the difference in our luckless chance.
I fear mine own, wish thy deliverance.
Our hearts shall hourly visit, I'll send to thee,Exit Fitz, with officers
Then 'tis no prison where the mind is free.
So, let him go, now wench I bring thee joys,
A fair sunshine after this angry storm:
It was my policy to remove this beggar:
What shall rich men wed their only daughters
To two fair suits of clothes? and perhaps yet
The poor tailor is unpaid; no, no my gentle,
I have a lad of thousands coming in;
Suppose he have more wealth than wit to guide it ▪
Why, there's thy gains, thou keepest the keys of all
Disposest all: and for generation,
Man does most seldom stamp they from the brain,
Wise-men begets fools, and fools are the fathers
To many wise children. Histeron, proteron,
A great scholar may be an idiot,
And from the plow tail may come a great scholar:
Nay, they are frequent propagations.
Ha? not well my girl?
Thou shalt have a physician then,
The best that gold can fetch upon his foot-cloth,
Thou knowest my tender pity to thee ever,
want nothing that thy wishes can instruct thee
To call for, 'fore me, and thou lookest half ill indeed,
But I'll bring one within a day to thee
Shall rouse thee up: for he's come up already,
One m. Chaugh a Cornish gentleman:
Has as much land of his own fee-simple,
As a crow can fly over in half a day:
And now I think on't, at the crow at Algate
His lodging is, he shall so stir thee up,
Come, come, be cheered, think of thy preferment,
Honour and attendance, these will bring thee health
And the way to they is to climb by wealth. Exeunt.

div.head: Actus secundus, scaena primae.

lg.l: The son of a whore?
There is not such another murdering piece
In all the stock of calumny: it kills
At one report two reputations,
A mother's and a son's: if it were possible
That souls could fight after the bodies fell,
This were a quarrel for 'em; he should be one indeed
That never heard of heaven's joys or hell's torments
To fight this out: I am too full of conscience,
Knowledge and patience, to give justice to't,
So careful of my eternity, which consists
Of upright actions: that unless I knew
It were a truth I stood for, any coward
Might make my breast his footpace, and who lives
That can assure the truth of his conception,
More than a mother's carriage makes it hopeful.
And is't not miserable valour then,
That man should hazard all upon things doubtful
O there's the cruelty of my foe's advantage,
could but my soul resolve my cause were just,
Earth's mountain, nor seas surge should hide him from me,
E'en to hell's threshold would I follow him,
And see the slanderer in before I left him,
But as it is it fears me, and I never
Appeared too constionably just till now:
My good opinion of her life and virtues,
Bids me go on: and fain would I be ruled by't,
But when my judgement tells me she's but woman,
Whose frail to let in death to all mankind,
My valour shrinks at that, certain she's good,
There only wants but my assurance in't,
And all things then were perfect how I thirst for't,
Here comes the only she that could resolve,
But 'tis too vild a question to demand indeed.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Son I've a suit to you.

lg.l: That may do well.
To me good madam, you're most sure to speed in't.
Beet i'my power to grant it,
'Tis my love
Makes the request, that you would never part
From England more,
With all my heart 'tis granted,
I'm sure I'm i'th way never to part from't,

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Where left you your dear friend the colonel?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: O the dear colonel, I should meet him soon,

lg.l: O fail him not then, he's a gentleman
The same and reputation of your time
Is much engaged to.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Yes, and you knew all mother.

lg.l: I thought I'd known so much of his fair goodness,
More could not have been looked for.
O yes, yes madam.
And this his last exceeded all the rest.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: For gratitude's sake let me know this, I pray thee.

lg.l: Then thus, and I desire your censure freely,
Whether it appeared not a strange noble kindness in him.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Trust me I long to hear't,

lg.l: You know he's hasty,
That by the way.
So are the best conditions
Your father was the like.
I begin now
To doubt me more, why am not I so too then,
Blood follows blood through forty generations,
And I've a slow paced wrath, a shrewd dilemma,

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Well, as you were saying sir,

lg.l: Marry thus good madam,
There was in company a foul mouthed villain, stay, stay,
Who should I liken him to, that you have seen,
He comes so near one that I would not match him with,
Faith just a'th colonel's pitch, he's never the worse man,
Usurers have been compared to magistrates,
Extortioners to lawyers, and the like,
But they all prove never the worse men for that,

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: That's bad enough, they need not,

lg.l: This rude fellow,
A shame to all humanity or manners,
Breathes from the rottenness of his gall and malice,
The foulest stain that ever man's same blemished,
Part of which fell upon your honour madam,
Which heightened my affliction.
The colonel soon enraged,
(As he's all touchwood)
Takes fire before me, makes the quarrel his,
Appoints the field, my wrath could not be heard
His was so high pitched, so gloriously mounted,
Now what's the friendly fear, that fights within me,
Should his brave noble fury undertake,
A cause that were unjust in our defence,
And so to lose him everlastingly,
In that dark depth where all bad quarrels sink,
Never to rise again, what pity 'twere,
First to die here and never to die there.
Why what's the quarrel, speak sir: that should raise
Such fearful doubt, my honour bearing part o't:
The words whate'er they were:
Thou liest, and were my love ten thousand times more to thee,
Which is as much now, as ere mothers was,
So thou shouldst feel my anger. Dost thou call
That quarrel doubtful; where are all my merits,Strikes him.
Not one stand up to tell this man his error.
Thou mightst as well bring the sun's truth in question,
As thy birth or my honour.
Now blessings crown you for't,
It is the joyfull'st blow that ere flesh felt.
Nay stay, stay sir, thou art not left so soon,
This is no question to be slighted of,
And at your pleasure closed up fair again,
As though you'd never touched it, no honour doubted,
Is honour deeply wounded, and it rages
More than a common smart, being of thy making.
For thee to fear my truth, it kills my comfort,
Where should fame seek for her reward, when he
That is her own by the great tie of blood,
Is farthest of in bounty, oh poor goodness!
That only payest thyself with thy own works,
For nothing else looks towards thee. Tell me pray,
Which of my loving cares dost thou requite
With this vild thought? which of my prayers or wishes?
Many thou owest me for, this seven year hast thou known me
A widow, only married to my vow:
That's no small witness of my faith and love
To him that in life was thy honoured father,
And live I now to know that good mistrusted.
No, 'tshall appear that my belief is cheerful,
For never was a mother's reputation
Noblier defended, 'tis my joy and pride,
I have a firm to bestow upon it.
'Twere too bold, and soon yet
to crave forgiveness of you. I will earn it first,
Dead or alive, I know I shall enjoy it.
My joys beyond expression:
I do but think how wretched I had been,
Were this another's quarrel, and not mine.
Mine! Think me not so miserable,
Not to be mine: then were I worse than abject,
More to be loathed then vileness; or sins dunghill:
Nor did I fear your goodness (Faithful madam)
But came with greedy joy to be confirmed in't,
To give the nobler onset, then shines valour,
And admiration from her fix't sphere draws,
When it comes burnished with a righteous cause,
Without which I'm ten fathoms under coward,
That now am ten degrees above a man,
Which is but one of virtues easiest wonders.
But pray stay; all this while I understood you,
The colonel was the man
Yes, he's the man,
The man of injury, reproach and slander,
Which I must turn into his soul again.
The villain did it:
That's not so strange; — your blessing and your leave

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Come, come, you shall not go.

lg.l: Not go; were death
Sent now to summon me to my eternity,
I'd put him off an hour: why the whole world
Has not chains strong enough to bind me from't:
The strongest is my reverence to you,
Which if you force upon me in this case;
I must be forced to break it.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: In any thing command me but in this madam.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Lass, I shall lose him, you'll hear me first.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: You'll never hear me more then.

lg.l: Come back I say:
You may well think there's cause I call so often.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: So much, you must not go.

lg.l: I know a reason for't,
Which I could wish you'd yield to, and not know
If not, it must come forth. Faith, do not know,
And yet obey my will.
Why I desire
To know no other than the cause I have,
Nor should you wish it, if you take your injury
For one more great, I know the world includes not.
Yes, one that makes this nothing, — yet be ruled,
And if you understand not, seek no further.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: I must, for this is nothing.

lg.l: Then take all,
And if amongst it you receive that secret
That will offend you, though you condemn me,
Yet blame yourself a little, for perhaps
I would have made my reputation sound
Upon another's hazards with less pity;
But upon yours I dare not.
I dare not,
'T was your own seeking; this,
If you mean evilly
I cannot understand you, nor for all the riches
This life has, would I.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Why, your goodness, that I joy to fight for.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: In that you neither right your joy nor me.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: What an ill orator has virtue got here?
Why, shall I dare to think it a thing possible

lg.l: O fearfully!
As much as you come to.
O silence, cover me.
I've felt a deadlier wound than man can give me, false?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: I was betrayed to a most sinful hour.
By a corrupted soul I put in trust once.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Where is she? let me pay her.

lg.l: Nay then sh'as all her wages:
False, do not say't, for honour's goodness do not,
You never could be so, he I called father,
Deserved you at your best, when youth and merit
Could boast at highest in you, you'd no grace,
Or virtue that he matched not, no delight
That you invented but he sent it crowned
To your full wishing soul.

sp.speaker: Captain

lg.l: O, were you so unhappy to be false,
Both to yourself and me, but to me chiefly,
What a day's hope is here lost, and with it
The joys of a just cause. Had you but thought
On such a noble quarrel, you'd ha' died
Ere you'd ha' yielded, for the sins hate first,
Next for the shame of this hours cowardice:
Cursed be the heat that lost me such a cause,
A work that I was made for. Quench my spirit,
And out with honour's flaming lights within thee:
Be dark and dead to all respects of manhood,
I never shall have use of valour more:
Put off your vow for shame, why should you hoard up
Such justice for a barren widowhood,
That was so injurious to the faith of wedlock. Exit lady.
I should be dead, for all my life's works ended,
I dare not sight a stroke now, nor engage
the noble resolution of my friends,

sp.stage: Enter two friends of captain Ager's.

lg.l: That were more vild. Their here, kill me my shame,
I am not for the fellowship of honour.
Captain, fie come sir, we have been seeking for you
Very late today, this was not wout to be,
Your enemies ith' field,

sp.speaker: 2 friend.
sp.l: Good faith sir you've a royal quarrel on't,

lg.l: Yes, in some other country, Spain or Italy.
It would be held so.

sp.speaker: 1 friend.
sp.l: How, and is't not here so?

lg.l: 'Tis not so contumeliously received
In these parts, and you mark it.
Not in these?
Why prithee what is more, or can be?
Yes,
That ordinary commotioner the lie
Is father of most quarrels in this climate,
And held here capital, and you go to that.
But sir, I hope you will not go to that,
Or change your own for it, son of a whore,
Why there's the lie down to posterity.
The lie to birth, the lie to honesty,
Why would you cozen you self so, and beguile
So brave a cause, manhood's best master piece,
Do you ever hope for one so brave again.
Consider then the man colonel,
Exactly worthy, absolutely noble,
However spleen and rage abuses him:
And 'tis not well, nor manly to pursue
A man's infirmity.
O miracle!
So hopeful, valiant and complete a captain,
Possessed with a tame devil, come out, thou spoilest
The most improved young soldier of seven kingdoms,
Made captain at nineteen, which was deserved
the year before, but honour comes behind still,
Come out I say, this was not wont to be,
That spirit never stood in need of provocation,
Nor shall it now. Away sir.

sp.speaker: 1. F.
sp.l: By manhood's reverend honour but we must.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: I will not fight a stroke.

lg.l: O blasphemy
To sacred valour!

sp.speaker: 1. Friend.
sp.l: Pardon this traitorous slumber, clogged with evils.

div.stage: Give captains rather wives then such tame devils.

lg.l: Nay master, you must not be covered to me,
The patient must open to the physician
All her dearest sorrows: art is blinded else,
And cannot show her mystical effects.
Can art be so dim-sighted, learned sir?
I did not think her so in capacious:
You train me (As I guess) like a conjurer,
One of our five oraculous wizards,
Who from the help of his examinant,
By the near guess of his suspicion
Appoints out the thief by the marks he tells him:
Have you no skill in physiognomy?
What colour (Says your coat) is my disease?
I am unmarried, and it cannot be yellow,
If it be maiden green, you cannot miss it.
I cannot see that vacuum in your blood:
But gentlewoman, if you love yourself,
Love my advice, be free and plain with me,
Where lies your grief?
Where lies my grief indeed?
I cannot tell the truth where my grief lies,
But my joy's imprisoned.
Lord, what plain questions you make problems of,
your art is such a regular high way
That put you out of it, and you are lost:
My heart is imprisoned in my body, sir:
There's all my joy, and my sorrow too
Lies very near it.
They are bad adjuncts,
Your joy and grief lying so near together,
Can propagate no happy issue, remove
The one (And let it be the worst) your grief,
If you'll propose the best unto your joy.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.l: Why, now comes your skill: what physic for it?

sp.speaker: Physician
sp.l: Now I have found you out, you are in love.

lg.l: I think I am, what your appliance now?
Can all your Paracelsian mixtures cure it,
'T must be a surgeon of the civil law,
I fear that must cure me.
Gentlewoman,
If you knew well my heart, you would not be
So circular, the very common name
Of physician might reprove your niceness,
We are as secret as your confessors,
And as firm obliged, 'tis a fine like death
For us to blab.
I will trust you, yet sir,
I had rather do it by attorney to you,
I else have blushes that will stop my tongue
Have you no friend so friendly as yourself
Of mine own sex, to whom I might impart
My sorrows to you at the second hand.
Why law, there I hit you, and be confirmed,
I'll give you such a bosom counsellor,
That your own tongue shall be sooner false to you,
Make yourself unready, and be naked to her:
I'll fetch her presently. Exit physician.
I must reveal
My shame will else take tongue, and speak before
'Tis a necessity impulsive drives me: me,
o my hard fate, but my more hard father,
That father of my fate, a father said I?
What a strange paradox I run into,
I must accuse two fathers of my fate
And fault, a reciprocal generation,
The father of my fault would have repaired,
His faulty issue, but my fate's father hinders it:
Then fate and fault, wherever I begin,
I must blame both, and yet 'twas love did sin.

div.stage: Enter physician, and Anne his sister.

lg.l: Look you mistress, here's your closer put in,
What you please, you ever keep the key of it,
With all my heart,
I will be more than mine ears length from you.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.l: You hold some endeared place with this gent.

lg.l: He's my brother forsooth, I his creature,
He does command me any lawful office
Either in act or counsel.
I must not doubt you,
Your brother has protested secrecy,
And strengthened me in you: I must lay open
A guilty sorrow to you: I am with child,
'Tis no black swan I show you, these spots stick
Upon the face of many go for maids,
I that had face enough to do the deed,
Cannot want tongue to speak it: but 'tis to you,
Whom I accept my helper.
Mistress, 'tis locked
Within a castle that's invincible,
It is too late to wish it were undone.
I have scarce wish within myself so strong
For understand me, 'tis not all so ill,
As you may yet conceit it: this deed was done
When heaven had witness to the jugal knot,
only the barren ceremony wants.
Which by an adverse father is abridged.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.l: Would my pity could help you.

lg.l: Your counsel may.
My father yet shoots widest from my sorrow,
And with a care indulgent seeing me changed
From what I was, sends for your good brother
To find my grief, and practise remedy:
You know it, give it him, but if a fourth
Be added to this counsel: I will say
Ye 'Are worse than you can call me at the worst.
At this advantage of my reputation.
I will revive a reputation,
That women long has lost, I'll keep counsel.
I'll only now oblige my teeth to you,
And they shall bite the blabber if it offer
To breathe on an offending syllable.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.l: I trust you, go, whisper, here comes my father.

lg.l: Sir. you are welcome, more and most welcome,
All the degrees of welcome: thrice welcome sir.

sp.speaker: Chaw.
sp.p: I'll show her the Cornish hug, sir, — I have kissed you now sweet heart, and I never do any kindness to my friends, but I use to hit 'em in the teeth with it presently.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: My name is Trimtram forsooth, look what my master does, I use to do the like.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.p: You are deceived, sir, I am not this gentlewoman's servant, to make your courtesy equal.

sp.speaker: Chaw.
sp.p: You do not know me mistress.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: No indeed, I doubt I shall learn too soon.

sp.speaker: Chaw.
sp.p: My name is Chawgh, a Cornish gentleman, my man's mine own countryman too i'faith: I warrant, you took us for some of the small islanders.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: I did indeed, between the Scotch and Irish.

sp.speaker: Chaw.
sp.p: Redshanks: I thought so by my truth, no truly, we are right Cornish diamonds.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: Yes, we cut out quarrels, and break glasses, where we go,

lg.l: If it be hidden from her father, yet
His ignorance understands well his knowledge,
For this (I guess) to be some rich coxcomb
He'd put upon his daughter,
Then only she's beholding to out help
For the close delivery of her burden,
Else all's overthrown.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: And pray be faithful in that. sir.

lg.l: Tush, we physicians are the truest
Alchemists, that from the ore and dross of sin,
Can new distil a maidenhead again.

sp.speaker: Russ.
sp.l: How do you like her sir?

sp.speaker: Chaw.
sp.p: Troth I do like her sir in the way of comparison to any thing that a man would desire. I am as high as the mount in love with her already, and that's as far as I can go by land, but I hope to go further by water with her one day.

lg.l: I tell you sir, she has lost some colour,
By wrestling with a peevish sickness now of late.

sp.speaker: Chaw.
sp.p: Wrestle? nay and she love wrestling, I'll teach her a trick to overthrow any peevish sickness in London, whate'er it be.

lg.l: Well, she had a rich beauty though I say't,
Nor is it lost: a little thing repairs it.

sp.speaker: Chaw.
sp.p: She shall command the best thing that I have in Middlesex, i'faith.

lg.l: Well sir, talk with her, give her a relish
Of your good liking to her, you shall have time
And free access to finish what you now begin,
What means my father? my love's unjust restraint,
My shame were it published, both together
Could not afflict me like this odious fool:
Now I see why he hated my Fitzallen.

sp.speaker: Chaw.
sp.p:
Sweet lady, your father says you are a wrestler,
if you love that sport, I love you the better. I'faith I love it as well as I love my meat after supper, 'tis indeed meat, drink and cloth to me.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.l: Methinks it should tear your clothes, sir.

sp.speaker: Chaw.
sp.p: Not a rag i'faith: Trimtram hold my cloak, — I'll wrestle a fall with you now, I'll show you a trick that you never saw in your life.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.l: O good sir for bear, I am no wrestler.

sp.speaker: Physician
sp.l: Good sir take heed, you'll hurt the gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Chaw.
sp.p: I will not catch beneath the waste believe it, I know fair play,

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.l: 'Tis no woman's exercise in London, sir.

sp.speaker: Chaw.
sp.p: I'll ne'er believe that, the hug and the lock between man and woman, with a fair fall, is as sweet an exercise for the body, as you'll desire in a summer's evening.

sp.speaker: Physician
sp.l: Sir, the gentlewoman is not well,

sp.speaker: Chaw,
sp.l: It may be you are a physician, sir.

sp.speaker: Chaw.
sp.p: I say then, and I'll stand to't, three ounces of wrestling with two hips, a yard of a green gown put together in the intourne, is as good a medicine for the green sickness as ever breathed.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Come sir, take your cloak again, I see here will be never a match.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: A match? I'd rather be matched from a musket's mouth, and shot unto my death.

sp.speaker: Chaw,
sp.l: I'll wrestle with any man for a good supper.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: I marry sir, I'll take your part there, catch that catch may.

lg.l: Sir, she is willing to't. There at my house,
She shall be private, and near to my attendance,
I know you not mistrust my faithful care,
I shall return her soon and perfectly.
Take your charge sir, go with this gentleman (Jane)
But prithee look well this way, ere thou goest,
'Tis a rich simplicity of great estate:
A thing that will be ruled, and thou shalt rule,
Consider of your sex's general aim,
that domination is a woman's heaven.

sp.speaker: Chaw.
sp.p: I will part at Dartmouth with her, sir, o that thou didst but love wrestling, I would give any man three foils on that condition.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: There's three sorts of men that would thank you for they, either cutlers, fencers, or players.

sp.speaker: Russ.
sp.p: Sir as I began, I end, wondrous welcome.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: What, will you go to school today? you are entered you know, and your quarterige runs on.

sp.speaker: Chaw.
sp.p: What? to the roaring school? pox on't, 'tis such a damnable noise, I shall never attain it neither: I do wonder they have never a wrestling school, that were worth twenty of your fencing or dancing schools.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Well, you must learn to roar here in London, you'll never proceed in the reputation of gallantry else.

sp.speaker: Chaw.
sp.p: How long has roaring been an exercise, thinkest thou Trimtram.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Ever since guns came up, the first was your roaring Meg

sp.speaker: Ch. Meg ▪
sp.p: Then 'twas a woman was the first roarer:

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Ay, a fire of her touchhole, 'That cost many a proper man's life since that time: and then the lions they learned it from the guns, living so near they, than it was heard to the Bankside, and the bears they began to roar: then the boys got it, and so ever since there have been a company of roaring boys.

sp.speaker: Chaw.
sp.p: And how long will it last, thinkest thou?

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: As long as the water runs under London bridge, or watermen at Westminster stairs.

sp.speaker: Chaw.
sp.p: Well, I will begin to roar too, since it is in fashion, o Corineus, this was not in thy time, I should have heard on't by the tradition of mine ancestors (For i' me sure there were choughs in thy days) if it had been so, when Hercules and thou wert on the Olympic mount together, then was wrestling in request.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Ay, and that mount is now the mount in Cornwall. Corineus brought it thither under one of his arms, they say.

sp.speaker: Chaw.
sp.p: O Corineus my predecessor: that I had but lived in those days to see thee wrestle, on that condition I had died seven year ago.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Nay, it should have been a dozen at least, i'faith, on that condition. Exeunt.

div.head: Actus tertius. Scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter captain Ager with his two friends.

lg.l: Our wills? our loves, our duties
To honoured fortitude: what wills have we
But our desires to nobleness and merit?
Valour's advancement, and the sacred rectitude
Due to a valorous cause.
War has his court of justice, that's the field,
Where all cases of manhood are determined,
And your case is no mean one.
True, than 'twere virtuous:
But mine is in extremes, foul and unjust:
Well, now you've got me hither, you're as far
To seek in your desire, as at first minute:
For by the strength and honour of a vow,
I will not lift a finger in this quarrel.
How? not in this? be not so rash a sin:
Why sir, do you ever hope to fight again then
Take heed on't, you must never look for that,
Why the universal stock of the world's injury,
Will be too poor to find a quarrel for you:
Give up your right and title to desert, sir,
If you fail virtue here, she needs you not:
All your time after, let her take this wrong,
And never presume then to serve her more:
bid farewell to the integrity of arms,
And let that honourable name of soldier
Fall from you like a shivered wreath of laurel
By thunder struck from a desertless forehead,
That wears another's right by usurpation.
Good captain, do not wilfully cast away
At one hour all the same your life has won:
This is your native seat, here you should seek
Most to preserve it, or if you will dote
So much on life (Poor life) which in respect
Of life in honour is but death and darkness
That you will prove neglectful of yourself,
Which is to me too fearful to imagine,
Yet for that virtuous lady's cause (Your mother)
Her reputation, dear to nobleness
As grace to penitence, whose fair memory,
E'en crowns fame in your issue, for that blessedness,
Give not this ill place, but in spite of hell,
And all her base feats, be exactly valiant,
Why, well said, thetes fair hope in that,
Another such a one.
Came they in thousands?
'Tis all against you.
Then poor friendless merit,
Heaven be good to thee, thy professor leaves thee:

sp.stage: Enter colonel and his two friends.
sp.l: He's com'd, do but you draw, we'll fight it for you.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: I know too much to grant that.

lg.l: O dead manhood!
Had ever such a cause so faint a servant?
Shame brand me if I do not suffer for him.
I've heard sir, you've been guilty of much boasting,
For your brave earliness at such a meeting,
You've lost the glory of that way this morning:
I was the first today.
So were you ever.
In my respect sir.
I never thought on victory our mistress
With greater reverence than I have your worth,
Nor ever loved her better.

sp.p: 'Slight, I could knock his brains about his heels, methinks .

lg.l: Success in you has been my absolute joy,
And when I have wished content, I have wished your friendship.
Stay, let me but run him through the tongue a little,
There's lawyer's blood in't, you shall see foul geere straight

sp.l: Come you are as mad now, as he's cowardous.

sp.speaker: Colonel
sp.l: I came not hither sir for an encomium.

lg.l: No, the more coxcomb he, that claws the head
Of your vain glory with't!
I came provided
For storms and tempests, and the foulest season
That ever rage let forth, or blew in wildness
From the incensed prison of man's blood.
'Tis otherwise with me, I come with mildness,
Peace, constant amity, and calm forgiveness,
The weather of a cristian and a friend.

sp.l: Give me a valiant Turk, though not worth ten pence, rather.

lg.l: Yet sir, the world will judge the injury mine.
Insufferable mine, mine beyond injury,
Thousands have made a less wrong reach to hell,
Ay, and rejoiced in his most endless vengeance,
(A miserable triumph, though a just one)
But when I call to memory our long friendship
Methinks it cannot be too great a wrong.
That then I should not pardon, why should man,
For a poor hasty syllable or two,
(And vented only in forgetful fury)
Chain all the hopes and riches of his soul
To the revenge of that, die, lost for ever:
For he that makes his last peace with his maker
in anger, anger is his peace eternally:
He must expect the same return again,
Whose venture is deceitful. Must he not sir?
I see what I must do, fairly put up again:
For here'll be nothing done, I perceive that,
What shall be done in such a worthless business
But to be sorry, and to be forgiven.
You sir to bring repentance, and I pardon.
If it be too much
To say repentance: call it what you please sir:
Choose your own world, I know you're sorry for't, and that's as good.
I sorry? by fame's honour, I am wronged:
Do you seek for peace, and draw the quarrel larger?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Then 'tis: I'm sorry that I thought you so.
A captain, I could gnaw his title of.

lg.l: Nor is it any misbecoming virtue, sir,
In the best manliness to repent a wrong,
Which made me bold with you.

sp.l: I could cuff his head off,
Pox on him, I could eat his buttock baked methinks .

lg.l: So, once again take thou thy peaceful rest then,
But as I put thee up: I must proclaim
This captain here, both to his friends and mine,
That only came to see fair valour righted,Offers to go away.
A base submisive coward; so I leave him.
O, heaven has pitied my excessive patience,
And sent me a cause: now I have a cause:
A coward I was never: — come you back sir?
'Tis such base mettle sir: 'twill not be taken,
It must home again with you.

sp.l: Impossible, coward do more than bastard?

lg.l: I prithee mock me not, take heed you do not,
For if I draw once more, I shall grow terrible,
And rage will force me do what will grieve honour.
He smiles, dare it be he? what think you gentlemen?
Your judgements, shall I not be cozened in him?
This cannot be the man? why he was bookish,
Made an invective lately against fighting,
A thing introth that moved a little with me,
Put up a fouler contumely far
Then thousand cowards came to, and grew thankful
Blessed remembrance in time of need?
I'd lost my honour else.
I never felt a more severe necessity.
Then came thy excellent pity. -. Not yet ready?
Have you such confidence in my just manhood:
That you dare so long trust me, and yet tempt me
Beyond the toleration of man's virtue,
Why? would you be more cruel than your injury?
Do you first take pride to wrong me, and then think me
Not worth your fury, do not use me so:
I shall deceive you then: sir, either draw,
And that not slightingly, but with the care
Of your best preservation; with that watchfulness,
As you'd defend yourself from circular fire,
Your sins rage, or her lord, this will require it,
Or you'll be too soon lost for I've an anger
Has gathered mighty strength against you: mighty;
Yet you shall find it honest to the last,
Noble and fair.
I'll venture't once again.
And if't be but as true, as it is wondrous,
I shall have that I come for; your leave gent.
If he should do't indeed, and deceives all now:
Stay, by this hand he offers; fights i'faith.
Fights: by this light he fights sir.
Why let it pass, and 'twas, I'm sure, was somewhat,
What's that now.
O go to then,
I knew 'twas not far off: what a world's this?
Is coward a more stirring meat then bastard, my masters?
Put in more eggs for shame when you get children,
And make it true court custard. — ho? I honour thee:
'Tis right and fair, and he that breathes against it,
He breathes against the justice of a man,
And man to cut him off: 'tis no injustice.
Thanks, thanks, for this most unexpected nobleness.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Truth never fails her servant, sir, nor leaves him with the day's shame upon him.

lg.l: Thou'st redeemed
Thy worth to the same height 'twas first esteemed.
Alas, how is it sir: give us some hope
Of your stay with us: let your spirit be seen
Above your fortune, the best fortitude
Has been of fate ill friended: now force your empire,
And reign above your blood, spite of dejection,
Reduce the monarchy of your abler mind,
Let not flesh straighten it.
O, just heaven has found me,1
And turned the strings of my too hasty injuries
Into my own blood, I pursued my ruin,
And urged him passed the patience of an angel.
Could man's revenge extend beyond man's life:
This would ha' woken it, if this flame will light me
But till I see my sister: 'tis a kind one.
More I expect not from't, noble deserver:
Farewell most valiant, and most wronged of men,Exeunt, led by them.
Do but forgive me, and I am victor then.

div.stage: Enter physician, Jane, Anne, Dutch nurse with the child.

lg.l: Sweet fro, to your most indulgent care,
Take this my heart's joy, I must not tell you,
The value of this jewel in my bosom.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: Dat you may vell. sir, der can niet forstoore you.

lg.l: Indeed I cannot tell you, you know nurse,
These are above the quantity of prize,
Where is the glory of the goodliest trees
But in the fruit and branches? The old stock
Must decay, and sprigs, scions such as these
Must become new stocks from us to glory,
In their fruitful issue, so we are made
Immortal on by other.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.p: You spreke a most lieben fader, and ick fall do de best of tender nurses to dis infant, my pretty frokin.

lg.l: I know you will be loving, here sweet friend,Give. money.
Here's earnest of a large sum of love and coin.
To quit your tender care.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.l: I have some reason too,Gives her money.
To purchase your dear care unto this infant.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.p: You be de witness of de baptism, dat is, as you spreken: de godmother, ick vell forstoor it so.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.l: Yes, I am the bad mother: if it be offence. Aside.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.l: I must be a little kind too. Gives her money.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.p: Much thanks to you all: dis child is much beloven: and ick sall see much care over it.

lg.l: Farewell good sister: show her the way forth,
I shall often visit you, kind nurse.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: You sall be velcome. Exeunt Ann and nurse.

lg.l: O sir, what a friend have I found in you?
Where my poor power shall stay in the requital,
Yourself must from your fair condition
Make up in mere acceptance of my will.
O, pray you urge it not, we are not born
For ourselves only, self love is a sin,
But in our loving donatives to others,
Man's virtue best consists, love all begets,
without, all are adulterate and counterfeit.
Your boundless love I cannot satisfy,
But with a mental memory of your virtues,
Yet let me not engage your cost withal,
Beseech you then take restitution
Of pains and bounty which you have disbursed
For your poor debtor.
You will not offer it:
Do not esteem my love so mercenary,
To be the hire of coin? Sure, I shall think
You do not hold so worthily of me
As I wish to deserve.
Not recompense!
Then you will beggar me with too much credit,
If not sufficient, you preserve my name,
Which I had forfeited to shame and scorn:
Cover my vices with a veil of love,
Defend and keep me from a father's rage,
Whose love yet infinite (Not knowing this)
Might (Knowing) turn a hate as infinite:
Sure he would throw me ever from his blessings,
And cast his curses on me: yes, further,
Your secrecy keeps me in the state of woman:
For else what husband would choose me his wife:
Knowing the honour of a bride were lost.
I cannot number half the good you do me,
In the concealed retention of my sin,
Then make me not worse than I was before.
In my ingratitude, good sir.
Again.
I shall repent my love (If you'll so call't)
To be made such a hackney, give me coin?
I had as leave you gave me poison (Lady)
For I have art and antidotes gainest that,
I might take that, but this I will refuse.
Well you then teach me how I may requite you,
In some small quantity.
'T was that I looked for. Aside.
Yes, I will tell you lady a full quittance,
And how you may become my creditress.
Indeed I will lady,
Not in coin, mistress, for silver though white,
Yet it draws black lines: it shall not rule my palm
There to mark forth his base corruption:
Pay me again in the same quality
That I to you tendered, that's love for love:
Can you love me lady? you have confessed
My love to you.
Why faith then,
Pay me back that way.
Tush, our meanings are better understood
Than shifted to the tongue, it brings along
A little blabbing blood into our cheeks,
That shames us when we speak.
Fie, you do, make not yourself ignorant
In what you know, you have ta'en forth the lesson
That I would read to you.
Sure then I need not,
Read it again, sir.
Yes, it makes perfect,
You know the way unto Achilles spear,
If that hurt you, I have the cure you see.
Come, you're a good man, I do perceive you:
You put a trial to me, I thank you,
You're my just confessor, and believe me,
I'll have no further penance for this sin,
Convert a year unto a lasting ever,
And call't Apollo's smile, 'twas onces then never.

sp.speaker: Physician
sp.l: Pray you mistake me not, indeed I love you.

sp.speaker: Physician
sp.l: The deed that you have done.

lg.l: Away, you're a blackamoor, you love me?
I hate you for your love: are you the man
That in your painted outside seemed so white?
O, you're a soul dissembling hypocrite,
You saved me from a thief that yourself might rob me,
Skinned o'er a green wound to breed an ulcer.
Is this the practice of your physic college?
Have you yet uttered all your niceness forth?
If you have more, vent it, certes I think
Your first grant was not yielded with less pain,
If 'twere, you have your prize, yield it again.
Pray you, tell me sir, (I asked it before)
Is it a practice amongst you physicians.
Tush, that's a secret, we cast all waters.
Should I reveal, you would mistrust my counsel:
The lawyer and physician here agrees
To women clients they give back their fees,
And is not that kindness?
This for thy love,Spits,
Out, outside of a man: thou cinnamon tree,
That but thy bark hast nothing good about thee
The unicorn is hunted for his horn,
The rest is left for carrion: thou false man.
Thou'st fished with silver hooks and golden baits:
But I'll avoid all thy deceiving sleights.
Do what you lift, I will do something too:
Remember yet what I have done for you,
You've a good face now, but 'twill grow rugged.
Ere you grow old: old men will despise you:
Think on your grandam Helen the fairest Queen
When in a new glass she spied her old face:
She (Smiling) wept to think upon the change,
Take your time, you're crazed, you're an apple fallen
From the tree, if you be kept long, you'll rot.
Study your answer well, yet I love you.
If you refuse I have a hand above. Exit Phys.

sp.speaker: Jane.

lg.l: Poison thyself, thou soul empoisoner:
Of thine own practic drink the theory.
What, a white devil have I met withal?
What shall I do? What do? is't a question?
Nor shame, nor hate, nor fear, nor lust, nor force
(Now being too bad) shall ever make me worse,

sp.l: What have we here? A second spirit.

lg.l: Mistress,
I am sent to you.
As you receive it, my brother sent me,
And you know he loves you.
I heard say so;
But 'twas a false report.
Pray, pardon me, I must do my message,
Who lives (Commanded) must obey his keeper.
I must persuade you to this act of woman.
Indeed of strumpet,
He takes you at advantage of your fall,
Seeing you down before.
He's my brother mistress, and a curse on you
If ere you bless him with that cursed deed,
Hang him, poison him, he held out a rose,
To draw the yielding sense, which come to hand
He shifts, and gives a canker.
Ay, but mistress, now I consider it,
Your reputation lies at his mercy,
Your fault dwells in his breast, say, he throw it out,
It will be known, how are you then undone?
Think on't, your good name, and they are not to be sold ▪
In every market, a good name's dear,
And indeed more esteemed than our actions,
by which we should deserve it.
What? do you shrink at that?
Would you not wear one spot upon your face,
To keep your whole body from a leprosy,
Though it were undiscovered ever, hang him,
Fear him not. Horseleeches suck out his corrupt blood,
Draw you none from him, less it be pure and good.
Then yet I have a friend; but thus exhort me,
And I have still a column to support me.
One fault heaven soon forgives, and 'tis on earth forgotten,
The moon herself is not without one spot. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter the lady Ager, meeting one of her servants.

lg.l: Now sir, where is he? speak, why comes he not?
I sent you for him; bless this fellow's senses:
What has he seen? A soul nine hours entranced,
Hovering twixt hell and heaven, could not wake ghastlier,
Not yet return an answer? What say you sir?
Where is he?
He is gone madam.
But as we heard, unwillingly he went
As ever blood enforced.

sp.speaker: 2 servant
sp.l: Madam, I fear, I ha' said too much already.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: These men are both agreed, speak, whether went he?

sp.speaker: 2. Se.
sp.l: Why to — I would you'd think the rest yourself madam.

lg.l: There came two urging gentlemen,
That called themselves his seconds, both so powerful,
As 'tis reported they prevailed with him,
With little labour.
O he's lost, he's gone,
For all my pains, he's gone; two meeting torrents
Are not so merciless as their two rages,
He never comes again, — wretched affection.
Have I belied my faith? injured my goodness?
Slandered my honour for his preservation?
Having but only him: and yet no happier.
'Tis then a judgement plain, truths angry with me,
In that I would abuse her sacred whiteness,
For any worldly temporal respect:
Forgive me then thou glorious woman's virtue,
Admired where ere thy habitation is,
Especially in us weak ones: o forgive me.
For 'tis thy vengeance this, to belie truth,
Which is so hardly ours, with such pain purchased
Fastings, and prayers, continence and care,
Misery must needs ensue: let him not die
In that unchaste belief of his false birth,
And my disgrace: whatever angel guides him,
May this request be with my tears obtained,
Let his soul know, my honour is unstained,
Run, seek, away, if there be any hope,Exeunt Seru.
Let me not lose him yet; when I think on him,
His dearness, and his worth, it earns me more,
They that know riches tremble to be poor.
My passion is not every woman's sorrow,
She must be truly honest feels my grief,
And only known to one, if such there be,
They know the sorrow that oppresseth me. Exit.

div.head: Actus quartus, scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter the colonels second .. Usher etc. with Chaugh and Trim.

sp.speaker: Second.
sp.p: Truth sir, I must needs blame you for a truant, having but one lesson read to you and neglect so soon: fie, I must see you once a day at least.

sp.speaker: Chaugh.
sp.p: Would I were whipped tutor if it were not long of my man Trimtram here.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Who, of me?

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Take't upon the trim. I'll give the five shillings, 'As I am a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: I'll see you whipped first: well, I will too; faith sir, I saw he was not perfect, and I was loath he should come before to shame himself.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: How? shame sir? is it a shame for scholars to learn? Sir, there are great scholars that are but slenderly read in our profession: sir, first it must be economical, the ecumenical: shame not to practise in the house how to perform in the field: the nail that is driven takes a little hold at the first stroke, but more at the second, and more at the third, but when 'tis home to the head, then 'tis firm.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: Faith I have been driving it home to the head this two days.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: I helped to hammer it in as well as I could too sir.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: Well sir, I will hear you rehearse anon, mean time peruse the exemplary of my bills, and tell me in what language I shall roar a lecture to you; or I'll read to you the mathematical science of roaring.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Is it mathematical?

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: O sir, does not the winds roar? the sea roar? the welkin roar? indeed, most things do roar by nature, and is not the knowledge of these things mathematical?

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Pray proceed sir.Reads his bill

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: The names of the languages, the sclanonian, Parthamenian, Barmeothian, Tiburnian, Wappinganian, or the modern Londonian. Any man or woman that is desirous to roar in any of these languages, in a week they shall be perfect, if they will take pains; so let 'em repair into Holborn to the sign of the cheat loaf.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: Now your bill speaks of that, I was wondering a good while at your sign, the loaf looks very like bread i'faith, but why is it called the cheat loaf?

sp.speaker: Second.
sp.p: This house was sometimes a baker's sir, that served the court where the bread is called cheat.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Ay, ay, 'twas a baker that cheated the court with bread.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: Well sir, choose your languages: and your lectures shall be read, between my usher and myself, for your better instruction, provided your conditions be performed in the premises beforesaid.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: Look you sir, there's twenty pound in hand, and twenty more, I am to pay when I am allowed a sufficient roarer.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: You speak in good earnest sir.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: Yes faith do I Trimtram shall be my witness.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Yes indeed sir, twenty pound is very good earnest.

sp.speaker: Vsher.
sp.p: Sir one thing I must tell you belongs to my place, you are the youngest scholar, and till another comes under you, there is a certain garnish belongs to the school, for in our practice we grow to a quarrel: then there must be wine ready to make all friends, for that's the end of roaring, 'tis valiant but harmless, and this charge is yours.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: With all my heart i'faith and I like it the better: because no blood comes on it, who shall fetch?

sp.speaker: 2. roar
sp.p: I'll be your spaniel sir.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: Bid vapour, bring some tobacco too,

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: Do and here's money for't. Exit 2. Roarer.

sp.speaker: Vsher.
sp.p: No, you shall not, let me see the money: so, I'll keep it, and discharge him after the combat, for your practice' sake you and your man shall roar him out on't, (For indeed you must pay your debts so: for that's one of the main ends of roaring) and when you have left him in a chafe, then I'll qualify the rascal.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: Content i'faith trim. we'll roar the rusty rascal out of his tobacco.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: I and he had the best craccus in London.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: Observe sir, we could now roar in the Slavonian language, but this practice hath been a little sublime: some hair's breadth or so above your caput; I take it for your use and understanding both it were fitter for you to taste the modern assault, only the Londonian roar.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p:
I'faith sir, that's for my purpose, for I shall use all my
roaring here in London: in Cornwall we are all for wrestling, and I do not mean to travel over sea to roar there.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: Observe then sir, but it were necessary you took forth your tables, to note the most difficult points for the better assistance of your memory.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: Nay sir, my man and I keep two tables.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Ay sir, and as many trenchers, cat's meat and dog's meat enough.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: Note sir, — dost thou confront my Cyclops?

sp.speaker: Usher
sp.p: With a Briarean brousted:

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: Cyclops.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Briarean.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: I know thee and thy lineal pedigree,

sp.speaker: Vsher.
sp.p: It is collateral: as Brutus and Posthumus.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Brutus.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: Posthumus.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: False as the face of Hecate; thy sister is a —

sp.speaker: Usher
sp.p: What is my sister centaur?

sp.speaker: Seco.
sp.p: I say thy sister is a Bronstrops.

sp.speaker: Usher
sp.p: A Bronstrops!

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: Tutor, tutor, ere you go any further, tell me the English of that, what is a Bronsterops pray.

sp.speaker: Se.
sp.p: A Bronsterops is in English a Hippocrene.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: A Hippocrene, note it trim. I love to understand the English as I go.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: What's the English of Hippocrene.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: Why Bronsterops?

sp.speaker: Usher
sp.p: Thou dost obtrect my flesh and blood,

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: Again, I denounce, thy sister is a fructifer,

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: What's that tutor?

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: That is in English a fucus or a minotaur.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: A minotaur:

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: A fucus.

sp.speaker: Usher
sp.p: I say thy mother is a callet, a panagron, a duplar and a syndicus.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: Dislocate thy Bladud.

sp.speaker: Usher
sp.p: Bladud shall conjure, if his daemons once appear,

div.stage: Enter 2. Roarer with wine, and vapour with tobacco.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: Advance thy respondency.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: Nay good gentleman, do not fall out, a cup of wine quickly Trimtram.

sp.speaker: Usher
sp.p: See my steel hath a glister,

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: Pray wipe him, and put him up again good usher.

sp.speaker: Usher
sp.p: Sir at your request I pull down the flag of defiance.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: Give me a bowl of wine my fury shall be quenched, here usher.

sp.speaker: Usher
sp.p: I pledge thee in good friendship.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: I like the conclusion of roaring very well i'faith.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: It has an excellent conclusion indeed, if the wine be good, always provided.

sp.speaker: Seco.
sp.p: O the wine must be always provided be sure of that.

sp.speaker: Usher
sp.p: Else you spoil the conclusion, and that you know crowns all.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: 'Tis much like wrestling i'faith: for we shake hands ere we begin: now that's to avoid the law, for then if he throw him a furlong into the ground, he cannot recover himself upon him, because 'twas done in cold friendship.

sp.speaker: Seco.
sp.p: I believe you sir.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: And then we drink afterwards, just in this fashion, wrestling and roaring are as like as can be i'faith, even like long sword and half pike.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: Nay they are reciprocal if you mark it, for as there is a great roaring at wrestling: so there is a kind of wrestling and contention at roaring.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: True i'faith, for I have heard they roar from the six windmills to Islington: those have been great falls then.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: Come, now a brief rehearsal of your other day's lesson, betwixt your man and you, and then for today we break up school.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: Come, Trimtram; if I be our tutor, I'll be bold to look in my tables, because I doubt I am scarce perfect.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: Well, well, I will not see small faults

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: The wall,

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: The wall of me, to thy kennel spaniel,

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: Wilt thou not yield precedency?

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: To thee, I know thee and thy brood

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p:
Know'st thou my brood, I know thy brood to,
thou art a rook;

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: The nearer a kin to the choughs?

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: The rooks a kin to the choughs?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: Very well maintained,

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: Dungcoer, thou liest,

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Lie, enucleate the kernel of thy scabbard,

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: Now if I durst draw my sword, 'twere valiant i'faith:

sp.speaker: Seco.
sp.p: Draw, draw, howsoever,

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: Have some wine ready to make us friends I pray you,

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Chaugh, I will make thee fly and roar,

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: I will roar if thou strikest me,

sp.speaker: Seco.
sp.p: So 'tis enough now conclude in wine, I see you will prove an excellent practitioner: wondrous well performed on both sides:

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: Here Trimtram I drink to thee,

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: Is there not one master Chaugh here,

sp.speaker: Usher
sp.p: This is the gentleman sir;

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: My master, sir, your elected father in law, desires speedily to speak with you:

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: Friend I will follow thee, I would thou hadst come a little sooner, thou shouldst have seen roaring sport i'faith,

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: Sir I'll return that you are following,Exit servant

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: Do so: I'll tell thee tutor, I am to marry shortly, but I will defer it a while till I can roar perfectly, that I may get the upper hand of my wife on the wedding day, 'tmust be done at first or never.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: 'T will serve you to good use in that sir.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: How likest thou this Whister?

sp.speaker: Vap.
sp.p: Very valiantly i'faith sir,

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Tush, thou shalt see more by and by.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.p: I can stay no longer indeed sir, who pays me for my tobacco?

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: How, pay for tobacco, away ye sooty mouthed piper: you rusty piece of Martlemas bacon, away.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Let me give him a mark for't.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p:
No Trimtram, do not strike him, we'll only
roar out a curse upon him.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Well, do you begin then,

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: May thy roll rot, and thy pudding drop in pieces, being sophisticated with filthy urine.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: May sergeants dwell on either side of thee, to fright away thy two penny customers.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: And for thy penny ones, let them suck thee dry.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: When thou art dead, mayst thou have no other sheets to be buried in but mouldy tobacco leaves.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: And no strawings to stick thy carcase, but the bitter stalks.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Thy mourners, all greasy tapsters,

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: With foul tobacco pipes in their hats in stead of rotten rose marry: and last of all may my man and I live to see all this performed and, to piss reeking even upon thy grave

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: And last of all for me, let this epitaph be remembered over thee.

lg.l: Here coldly now within is laid to rot,
A man that yesterday was piping hot:
Some sap he died by pudding, some by prick,
Others by role and ball some lease, all stick
Fast in censure, yet think it strange and rare,
(He lived by smoke, yet died for want of air)
But then the surgeon said when he beheld him,
It was the burning of his pipe that killed him.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: So, are you paid now whistler?

sp.speaker: Vap.
sp.p: All this is but smoke out of a stinking pipe,

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: So, so, pay him now usher.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: Do not henceforth neglect your schooling m. Chaugh.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Call me rook if I do tutor.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: And me raven, though my name be Trimtram.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Farewell tutor.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Farewell usher.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: Thus when the drum's unbraced, and trumpet cease, soldiers must get pay for to live in peace.Exeunt

div.stage: Enter the colonel's sister, meeting the surgeon.

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.p:
O my most worthy brother, thy hard fate 'twas: come hither honest surgeon, and deal faithfully
with a distressed virgin: what hope is there?

sp.speaker: Surgeon
sp.p: Hope, Chillis was scaped miraculously lady.

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.p: What's that sir.

sp.speaker: Surgeon cava vena:
sp.p: I care but little for his wound ith' Orsophag, not thus much trust me, but when they come to diaphragma once, the small intestines, or the spinal medull, or i'th roots of the emunctories of the noble parts, then straight I fear a syncope; the flanks retiring towards the back, the urine bloody, the excrements purulent, and the dolour pricking or pungent.

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.p: Alas I'm ne'er the better for this answer.

sp.speaker: Surgeon
sp.p: Now I must tell you his principal dolour lies i'th region of the liver, and there's both inflammation and tumefaction feared, marry I made him a quadrangular plumation, where I used sanguis draconis; by my faith, with powders incarnative, which I tempered with oil of hypericon, and other liquours mundificative.

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.p: Pox a your mundies figatives, I would they were all fired,

sp.speaker: Surgeon
sp.p: But I purpose lady to make another experiment at next dressing with a sarcotic medicament, made of Iris of Florence. Thus mastic, Calaphena, Apopanax, sacrocolla:

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.p: Sacro-halter, what comfort is i'this to a poor gentlewoman; pray tell me in plain terms what you think of him?

sp.speaker: Surgeon
sp.p: Marry in plain terms I know not what to say to him, the wound I can assure you inclines to paralysm; and I find his body cacochemic: being then in fear of fever and inflammation, I nourish him altogether with viands refrigerative and give for potion the juice of savicola, dissolved with water cerefolium: I could do no more lady, if his best Guiguimos were dissevered. Exit.

lg.l: What thankless pains does the tongue often take,
To make the whole man most ridiculous:
I come to him for comfort, and he tires me
Worse than my sorrow, what a precious good
May be delivered sweetly in few words:
And what a mount of nothing has he cast forth.
Alas his strength decays: how cheer you sir,
My honoured brother?

sp.speaker: Colonel

lg.l: In soul never better.
I feel an excellent health there, such a stoutness,
My invisible enemy flies me, seeing me armed
With penitence and forgiveness, they fall backward,
Whether through admiration, not imagining
There were such armoury in a soldier's soul,
As pardon and repentance: or through power
Of ghostly valour? but I have been lord
Of a more happy conquest in nine hours now,
Then in nine years before: o kind lieutenants
This is the only war we should provide for,
Where he that forgives largest and sighs strongest,
Is a tried soldier, a true man in deed,
And wins the best field, makes his own heart bleed.
Read the last part of that will sir.

sp.p: I also require at the hands of my most beloved sister, whom I make full executrix, the disposure of my body in burial at s.
