Martin's i'th field: and to cause to be distributed to the poor of the same parish, forty mark, and to the hospital of maimed soldiers a hundred: lastly I give and bequeath to my kind, dear, and virtuous sister, the full possession of my present estate in riches, whether it be in lands, leases, money, goods, plate, jewels, or what kind soever, upon this condition following, that she forthwith, tender both herself and all these infeoffments, to that noble captain my late enemy captain Ager.

sp.speaker: Colonel
sp.l: Read it again sir, let her hear it plain.

lg.l: Pray spare your pains sir, 'tis too plain already.
Good sir, how do you, is your memory perfect?
This will makes question of you: I bestowed
So much grief and compassion a your wound,
I never looked into your sense's epilepsy:
The sickness and infirmity of your judgement
Is to be doubted now, more than your bodies,
why is your love no dearer to me sir,
Then to dispose me so upon the man,
Whose fury is your body's present torment?
The author of your danger: one I hate
Beyond the bounds of malice, do you not feel
His wrath upon you? I beseech you sir,
Alter that cruel article.
Cruel sister? (Forgive me natural love)
I must offend thee, speaking to this woman, am I content,
Having much kindred, yet to give thee all,
(Because in thee I'd raise my means to goodness)
And canst thou prove so thankless to my bounty,
To grudge my soul her peace? is my intent
To leave her rich, whose only desire is
To send me poorer into the next world,
Then ever usurer went, or politic statist?
Is it so burdensome for thee to love
Where I forgive? O wretched is the man
That builds the last hopes of his saving comforts
Upon a woman's charity? he's most miserable,
If it were possible, her obstinate will
Will pull him down in his midway to heaven,
I've wronged that worthy man passed recompense,
And in my anger robbed him of fair fame:
And thou the fairest restitution art
My life could yield him: if I knew a fairer,
I'd set thee by and thy unwilling goodness,
And never make my sacred peace of thee:
But there's the cruelty of a fate debarred,
Thou art the last, and all, and thou art hard.
Let your grieved heart hold better thoughts of me,
I will not prove so sir, but since you enforce it,
With such a strength of passion I'll perform,
What by your will you have enjoined me to,
Though the world never show me joy again.
O this may be fair cunning for the time,
To put me off, knowing I hold not long,
And when I look to have my joys accomplished,
I shall find no such things: that were vild cozenage,
And not to be repented.
By all the blessedness,
Truth and a good life looks for, I will do't sir,
Comforts reward you for't, when ere you grieve,
I know if you dare swear I may believe.Exeunt
No sooner have I entrance i'this house now,
But all my joy falls from me, which was wont
To be the sanctuary of my comforts:
Methought I loved it with a reverent gladness,
As holy men do consecrated temples
For the saint's sake, which I believed my mother,
But proved a false faith since, a fearful heresy,
Oh who'd erect th'assurance of his joys
Upon a woman's goodness? whose best virtue,
Is to commit unseen, and highest secrecy,
To hide but her own sin, there's their perfection,
And if she be so good, which many fail of to,
When these are bad, how wondrous ill are they,
What comfort is't to fight, win this day's fame,
When all my after days, are lamps of shame,
Blessings be firm to me, he's come 'tis he,
A surgeon speedily;
Perhaps you'll say 'tis but a little wound
Good to prevent a danger: quick, a surgeon,
Ay, ay, that's all the faust of valiant men,
They'll not be known a their hurts till they're past help,
And then to late they wish for't:
'Tis no disparagement to 'Confess a wound,
I'm glad sir 'tis no worse, a surgeon quickly,
Come, come sir, a wound's honourable,
And never shames the wearer,
By the justice
I owe to honour, I came of untouched,
My tears prevail then, welcome, welcome sir,
As peace and mercy to one new departed,
Why would you go though, and deceive me so,
When my abundant love took all the course
That might be to prevent it, I did that,
For my affection's sake, goodness forgive me for't,
That were my own life's safety put upon't,
I'd rather die than do't, think how you used me then,
'And yet would you go, and hazard yourself too,
'Twas but unkindly done.
See then how rash you were and short in wisdom,
Why wrong my faith I did, slandered my constancy,
Belied my truth, that which few mother's will,
Or fewer can, I did, out of true fear
And loving care, only to keep thee here.
I doubt I am too quick of apprehension, now
And that's a general fault, when we here joyfully,
With the desire of longing fort, I ask it:
Why? were you never false,
May death come to me,
Before repentance then?
I heard it plain sure,
Not false at all?
By the reward of truth,
I never knew that deed
That claims the name on't.
May then that glorious reward you swore by,
Be never failing to you, all the blessings
That you have given me since obedient custom
Taught me to kneel and ask they, are not valuable
With this immaculate blessing of your truth:
This is the palm to victory.
The crown for all deserts past, and to come,
let 'em be numberless, they are rewarded,
Already they're rewarded: bless this frame
I feel it much too weak to bear the joy on't.
O pardon me —
I cannot honour you too much, too long,
I kneel not only to a mother now,
But to a woman that was never false,
Year dear, and year good too: I think a that,
What reverence does she merit 'tis fit such
Should be distinguished from the prostrate sex,
And what distinction properer can be shown,
Then honour done to her that keeps her own,

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Come sir, I'll have you rise,

lg.l: To do a deed then,Rises.
That shall for ever raise me: oh my glory,
Why this, this is the quarrel that I looked for,
The tother but a shift to hold time play,
You sacred ministers of preservation,
For heaven's sake send him life,
And with it mighty health, and such a strength,
May equal but the cause, I wish no foul things,
If life but glow in him he shall know instantly
That I'm resolved to call him to account for't.
I bind you by your honour, madam,
You speak no hindrance to't,
Take heed, you ought not
What an unhappiness have I in goodness,
'Tis ever my desire to intend well
But have no fortunate way in't, for all this
Deserve I yet no better of you: but to be grieved again?
Are you not well with honest gain of fame,
With safety purchased, will you needs tempt a ruin,
That avoids you? Exit lady.
No you've prevailed: things of this nature sprung,
When they use action must use little tongue.
Now sir, the news?
Sir there's a gentlewoman,
Desires some conference with you.
How, with me?
A gentlewoman? what is she?
Her attendant
Delivered her to be the colonel's sister.
O for a storm then,
Alas poor virtuous gentlewoman,
I will endure her violence with much pity,
She comes to ease her heart good noble soul,
'Tis e'en a charity to release the burden,
Were, not that remedy ordained for women,
Their hearts would never hold three years together,
And here she comes, I never marked so much of her,
That face can be the mistress of no anger
But I might very well endure a month methinks ,
I am the man speak lady, I'll stand fair.
And I'm enjoined by vow to fall thus low,She kneels.
And from the dying hand of a repentant
Offer for expiation of wrongs done you,
Myself, and with myself all that was his,
Which upon that condition was made mine,
Being his soul's wish to depart absolute man,
In life a soldier death a christian.
O heaven has touched him nobly, how it shames
My virtues slow perfection: rise dear brightness,
I forget manners too, up matchless sweetness,
I must not sir, there is not in my vow
That liberty, I must be received first,
Or all denied, if either, I am free,
He must be without soul should deny thee,
And with that reverence I receive the gift,
As it was sent me, worthy colonel,
Has such a conquering way i'th blessed things,
Whoever overcomes, he only wins. Exit.

div.stage: Enter captain Albo, a bawd and a whore.

sp.speaker: Bawd
sp.p: Hark of these hard-hearted bloodhounds: these butchers are e'en as merciless as their dogs, they knock down a woman's fame, e'en as it walks the streets by 'em.

sp.speaker: Whore
sp.p: And the captain here that should defend us, walks by like John of the apple loft.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: What for interjections Prisse? Hem, euax, vah: let the carnisexes scour their throats: thou knowest there is a curse hangs over their bloody heads, this year there shall be more butchers pricks burned then of all trades besides.

sp.speaker: Bawd
sp.p: I do wonder how thou camest to be a captain.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: As thou camest to be a bawd Meg, and Prisse to be a whore, every one by their deserts.

sp.speaker: Bawd
sp.p: Bawd, and whore? out you unprofitable rascal, hast not thou been at the new play yet, to teach thee better manners: truly they say they are the finest players, and good speakers of gentlewomen of our quality; bawd and whore is not mentioned amongst they, but the handsomest narrow-mouthed names they have for us, that some of them may serve as well for a lady, as for one of our occupation.

sp.speaker: Whore
sp.p: Prithee patroness, let's go see a piece of that play: if we shall have good words for our money, 'tis as much as we can deserve i'faith.

sp.speaker: Bawd
sp.p: I doubt 'tis too late now, but another time servant.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Let's go now sweet face I am acquainted with one of the pantomimics, the bulchins will use the Irish captain with respect, and you two shall be boxed amongst the better sort.

sp.speaker: Whore
sp.p: Sirrah captain Albo, I doubt you are but white-livered, look that you defend us valiantly, you know your penance else: patroness, you remember how you used him once?

sp.speaker: Bawd
sp.p: I servant, and I shall never forget it, till I use him so again: do you remember captain?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Mum Meg, I will not hear on't now.

sp.speaker: Bawd
sp.p: How I and my Amazons stripped you as naked as an Indian.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Why Meg?

sp.speaker: Bawd
sp.p: And then how I bound you to the good behaviour, in the open fields.

sp.speaker: Whore
sp.p: And than you strewed oats upon his hoppers.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Prithee sweet face.

sp.speaker: Whore
sp.p: And then brought your ducks to nibble upon, him you remember?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: O, the remembrance tortures me again, no more good sweet face.

sp.speaker: Bawd
sp.p: Well, lead on sir: but hark a little.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: Didst thou bargain for the bladders with the butcher trim?

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Ay sir, I have they here, I'll practise to swim too sir, and then I may roar with the water at London bridge, he that roars by land and by water both, is the the perfect roarer.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: Well I'll venture to swim too: if my father in law gives me a good dowry with his daughter, I shall hold up my head well enough.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Peace, sir, here's practice for our roaring, here's a centaur, and two Hippocrenes.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: Offer the justle trim. Justle:

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Ha? What meanest thou by that?

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: I mean to confront thee, Cyclops.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: I'll tell thee what a means, is this thy sister?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: How then sir?

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: Why then I say she is a Bronsterops: and this is a fucus.

sp.speaker: Whore
sp.p: No indeed sir, we are both fucuses.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Art thou military? art thou a soldier?

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: A soldier, no I scorn to be so poor, I am a roarer.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: A roarer?

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Ay sir, two roarers.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Know then my fresh water friends, that I am a captain.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: What, and have but two to serve under you?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: I am now retiring the field.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: You may see that by his bag and baggage.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: Deliver up thy panagron to me.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: And give me thy syndicus.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Deliver?

sp.speaker: Bawd
sp.p: I pray you captain be contented, the gentlemen seem to give us very good words.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: Good words? I if you could understand they, the words cost twenty pound.

sp.speaker: Bawd
sp.p: What is your pleasure gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: I would enucleate my fructifer.

sp.speaker: Whore
sp.p: What says he patroness?

sp.speaker: Bawd
sp.p: He would inoculate: I understand the gentleman very pithily.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Speak, are you gentile or plebeian, can you give arms?

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: Arms? I sir, you shall feel our arms presently.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Salt you the women, I'll pepper him till he stinks again: I perceive what countryman he is, let me alone with him.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Darest thou charge a captain?

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Yes, and discharge upon him too.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Foh, 'tis poison to my country, the slave has eaten pippins: o shoot no more, turn both thy broadsides rather than thy poop: 'tis foul play: my country breeds no poison: I yield, the great oh tool shall yield on these conditions.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: I have given one of they a fair fall trim.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Then thus far we bring home conquest: follow me captain, the Cyclops doth command.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: Follow me Tweaks, the centaur doth command.

sp.speaker: Bawd
sp.p: Any thing sweet gentlemen, wilt please you to lead to the tavern, where we'll make all friends.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Why now you come to the conclusion.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: Stay, trim; I have heard your tweaks are like your mere maids, they have sweet voices to entice the passengers: let's have a song, and then we'll set they at liberty.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: In the commendation of roaring, not else sir,

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.l: Ay, in the commendation of roaring,

lg.head: Sing baud.
lg.l: Then here thou shalt resign
Both captain and commander,
That name was never thine,
But apple-squire and pander.
And henceforth will we grant,
In pillage or in moneys,
In clothing or provant,
whate'er we get by coneys:
With a hone, a hone, a hone,
No cheaters nor decoys,
Shall have a share, but alone
The bravest roaring boys.
What are we get by gulls,
Of country or of city:
Old flatcaps or young heirs,
Or lawyer's clerks so witty:
By sailors newly landed,
To put in for fresh waters:
By wand'ring gander-mooners:
Or muffled late night-walkers. with a, etc.
What are we get by strangers,
The Scotch, the Dutch, or Irish:
Or to come nearer home,
By masters of the parish.
It is concluded thus,
By all and every wench,
To take of all their coins,
And pay they back in French. with a, etc.

sp.speaker: Bawd
sp.p: We shall never be able to deserve these good words at your hands gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Shake golls with the captain, he shall be thy valiant friend.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: Not yet captain, we must make an end of our roaring first.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: We'll serve they as we did the tobacco-man: lay a curse upon they, marry we'll lay it on gently, because they have used us so kindly, and then we'll shake golls together.

sp.speaker: Whore
sp.p: As gently as you can, sweet gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.p: For thee, o pander: mayst thou trudge till the damned soles of thy boots fleet into dirt, but never rise into air.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Next, mayst thou fleet so long from place to place, till thou beest kicked out of Fleetstreet.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: As thou hast lived by bad flesh, so rotten mutton be thy bane.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: When thou art dead, may twenty whores follow thee, that thou mayst go a squire to thy grave.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Enough for me sweet faces, let me sleep in my grave.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.p: For thee old syndicus, may I see thee ride in a caroche with two wheels, and drawn with one horse.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Ten beadles running by, in stead of footmen.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: With every one a whip, steed of an Irish dart.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Forty barber's basins sounding before instead of trumpets.

sp.speaker: Bawd
sp.p: This will be comely indeed sweet gentlemen roarers.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Thy ruff starched yellow with rotten eggs.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: And mayst thou then be drawn from Holborn, to Hounslow-heath.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: And then be burned to Colebrooke for destroying of maidenhead.

sp.speaker: Bawd
sp.p: I will study to deserve this kindness at your hands gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: Now for thee little Fucus, mayst thou first serve out thy time as a tweak, and then become a Bronstrops as she is.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Mayst thou have a reasonable good spring, for thou art like to have many dangerous soul falls.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: Mayst thou have two ruffs torn in one week.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: May spiders only weave thy cobweb-lawn:

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: Mayst thou set up in rogue lane.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Live till thou stinkest in garden-alleys.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: And die sweetly in Tower-ditch.

sp.speaker: Whore
sp.p: I thank you for that good sir roarer.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.p: Come, shall we go now trim, my father in law stays for me all this while.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Nay, I'll serve they as we did the tobacco-man: I'll bury they altogether, and give they an epitaph.

sp.speaker: Chaugh.
sp.p: All together trim, why then the epitaph will be accessary to the sin: alas, he has kept the door all his life time, for pity let they lie together in their graves.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: E'en as thou wilt trim, and I thank you too sir.

lg.l: He that the reason would know, let him hark,
Why these two were buried near marrowbone park:
These three were a pander, a band, and a whore,
That sucked many dry to the bones before.
Well you know how they lived? here't may be red,
The low countries did ever find they bred,
They lived by Flushing, by sluice, and the greyne,
Sickened in France, and died under the line.
Three letters at last commended they hither,
But the hangman broke one in putting together.
P. was the first, who cries out for a pardon,
O. craves his book, yet could not read such a hard one,
An x. was the last, which in conjunction
Was broke by Brandon, and here's the conclusion.
By three trees, three letters; these three, pander, band, whore:
Now stink below ground, stunk long above before.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: So, now we have done with you, remember roaring boys.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Farewell centaur.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: Farewell Bronsterops.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Farewell Fucus.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Well Meg: I will learn to roar, and still maintain the name of captain over these lancepresadoes.

sp.speaker: Bawd
sp.p: If thou dost not, mayst thou be buried under the roaring curse. Exeunt.

div.head: Actus quintus, scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter physician: Jane as a bride.

sp.speaker: Physician
sp.p: Will you be obstinate?

lg.l: Torment me not,
Thou lingering executioner to death,
Greatest disease to nature, that strivest by art
To make men long a dying, your practice is
Upon men's bodies, as men pull roses,
For their own relish, but to kill the flower
So you maintain your lives by others deaths,
What eat you then by carrion?
Fie bitterness,
You'd need to candy o'er your tongue a little,
Your words will hardly be digested else,
You can give yourself a vomit to return they,
If they offend your stomach,
Here my vow
You are to be married today.
A second torment,
Worse than the first, cause unavoidable,
I would I could as soon annihilate
My fathers will in that as forbid thy lust.
If you then tender an unwilling hand,
Meet it with revenge, marry a cuckold.
If thou wilt marry me, I'll make that vow,
And give my body for satisfaction
To him that should enjoy me for his wife.

sp.speaker: Physician
sp.l: Go to, I'll mar your marriage.

lg.l: Do, plague me so.
I'll rather bear the brand of all that's past,
In capital characters upon my brow,
Then think to be thy whore or marry him,
I will produce thy bastard,
Bring thee to public penance,
No matter, I care not,
I shall 〈◊〉 have a clean sheet, I'll wear twenty
Rather then one defiled with thee.
Pursue it fully then, out of his hate,
I shall pursue (I hope) a loathed fate. Exit Jane
Am I rejected, all my baits nibbled off,
And not the fish caught? I'll trouble the whole stream,
And choke it in the mud, since hooks not take,
I'll throw in nets that shall or kill or break.
This is the bridegroom's man, hark sir, a word.
'Tis a busy day sir, nor I need no physic,
You see I scour about my business.

sp.speaker: Physician
sp.p: Pray you a word sir, your master is to be married today.

sp.speaker: Physician
sp.l: I would speak with your master sir.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: My master sir, is to be married this morning and cannot be within while soon at night.

lg.l: If you will do your master the best service,
That ere you did him, if he shall not curse
Your negligence hereafter slacking it:
If he shall bless me for the dearest friend
That ever his acquaintance met withal,
Let me speak with him ere he go to church.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: A right physician, you would have none go to the church, nor churchyard till you send them thither; well, if death do not spare you yourselves, he deals hardly with you, for you are better benefactors and send more to him then all diseases besides.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: What Trimtram, Trimtram?

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: I come sir. Hark you, you may hear him, he's upon the spur and would fain mount the saddle of matrimony, but (If I can) I'll persuade him to come to you. Exit Trim

lg.l: Pray you do sir: I'll teach all peevish niceness
to beware the strong advantage of revenge.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.l: Who's that would speak with me?

lg.l: None but a friend sir.
I would speak with you.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: Why sir, and I dare speak with any man under the universe, can you roar sir?

lg.l: No in faith sir.
I come to tell you mildly for your good,
If you please to hear me: you are upon marriages

sp.speaker: Chau
sp.p: No sir, I an towards it, but not upon it yet.

sp.speaker: Physician
sp.p: Do you know what you do?

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: Yes sir, I have practised what to do before now, I would be ashamed to be married else: I have seen a Bronstrops in my time, and a Hippocrene, and a tweke too.

sp.speaker: Physician
sp.p: Take fair heed sir, the wife that you would marry is not fit for you.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Why sir, have you tried her?

sp.speaker: Physician
sp.p: Not I believe it sir, but believe with all, she has been tried.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: Why sir, is she a fructifer? or a fucus?

sp.speaker: Physician
sp.p: All that I speak sir, is in love to you, your bride, that may be, 'Has not that portion that a bride should have.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: Why sir? she has a thousand and a better penny.

sp.speaker: Physician
sp.p: I do not speak of rubbish, dross, and o'er, but the refined mettle, honour sir.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: What she wants in honour shall be made up in worship sir, money will purchase both.

sp.speaker: Physician
sp.p: To be plain with you, she's naught.Draws his sword

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: If thou canst not roar thou'rt a dead man, my bride naught?

sp.speaker: Physician
sp.p: Sir, I do not fear you that way, what I speak, my life shall maintain, I say she's naught.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: Dost thou not fear me ▪

sp.speaker: Physician
sp.p: Indeed I do not sir.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: I'll never draw upon the while I live for that trick, put up and speak freely.

sp.speaker: Physician
sp.l: Your intended bride is a whore, that's freely sir,

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: Yes saith, a whore's free enough, and she hath a conscience: is she a whore? Foot I warrant she has the pox then?

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.l: A plaguy whore? A pox on her I'll none of her,

lg.l: Mine accusation shall have firm evidence.
I will produce an avoid witness,
A bastard of her bearing.

sp.speaker: Chau,
sp.p: A bastard? 'Snails, there's great suspicion she's a whore then, I'll wrestle a fall with her father for putting this trick upon me as I am a gentleman.

lg.l: Good sir mistake me not, I do not speak
To break the contract of united hearts,
I will not pull that curse upon my head,
To separate the husband and the wife,
But this (In love) I thought fit to reveal,
(As the due office betwixt man and man)
That you might not be ignorant of your ills,
Consider now of my premonishment,
As yourself shall please.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: I'll burn all the rose marry to sweeten the house, for in my conscience 'tis infected: has she drunk bastard? if she would piss me wine vinegar now nine times a day I'd never have her, and I thank you too.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Come, will you come away sir, they have all rosemary and stay for you to lead the way.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: I'll not be married today Trimtram, hast ere an almanac about thee? this is the nineteenth of August, look what day of the month 'tis. Looks in an almanac.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.l: What's the word? what says Bretnor?

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: The word is sir, there's a hole in her coat.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: I thought so, the physician agrees with him, I'll not marry today.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: I pray you sir, there will be charges for new rosemary else, this will be withered by tomorrow.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: Make a bon fire on't to sweeten rosemary lane prithee trim. entreat my father in law that might have been, to come and speak with me.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: The bride cries already and looks to their way, and you be so backward too, we shall have a fine arseward wedding on't. Exit Trim.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.l: You'll stand to your words, sir?

sp.speaker: Physician
sp.p: I'll not fly the house sir, when you have need call me to evidence. Exit physician.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: If you'll prove she has born a bastard, I'll stand to't she's a whore.

sp.speaker: Russ.
sp.p: Why how now son what causeth these delays? All stay for your leading.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.l: Came I from the mount to be confronted?

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: Why then I'll tell thee plainly thy daughter in a Bronstrops.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: Sir if she be so she is a Hippocrene.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.l: Nay worse she is a fructifer.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: Nay then she is a fucus, a minotaur, and a tweke.

sp.speaker: Russ.
sp.l: Pray you speak to my understanding sir,

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: If thou wilt have it in plain terms: she is a calicut, and a panagron.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: Nay then she is a duplar and a syndicus.

sp.speaker: Russ.
sp.l: Good sir, speak English to me.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: All this is Cornish to thee, I say thy daughter has drunk bastard in her time.

sp.speaker: Russ.
sp.l: Bastard you do not mean to make her a whore?

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: Yes but I do, if she make a fool of me, I'll ne'er make her my wife, till she have her maidenhead again?

sp.speaker: Russ.
sp.l: A whore? I do defy this calumny.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.l: Dost thou? I defy thee then.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Do you sir, than I defy thee too, fight with us both at once in this quarrel if thou darest.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.l: I could have had a whore at Plymouth.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: Or as you came, at evil.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.l: Or at Hockly hole in Somersetshire.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: Or at the hanging stones in Wiltshire.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: Or at maidenhead in Barkshire: and did I come in by maidenhead to go out by stains? O that man woman or child, would wrestle with me for a pound of patience.

lg.l: Some thief has put in poison at your ears.
To steal the good name of my child from me:
Or if it be a malice of your own,
Be sure I will enforce a proof from you.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: He's a goose and a woodcock that says I will not prove any word that I speak.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: I either goose or woodcock he shall sir with any man.

lg.l: Sir, with much sorrow for your sorrow's sake,
I must deliver this most certain truth,
Your daughter is an honour stayned bride,
Indeed she is the mother to a child,
Before the lawful wife unto a husband.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: La, that's worse than I told thee, I said she had born a bastard, and he says she was the mother on't too.

lg.l: I'm yet an infidel against all this,
And will believe the sun is made of brass,
The stars of amber.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.l: And the moon of a holland cheese.

sp.speaker: Russ.
sp.l: Rather than this impossibility, o, here she comes,

lg.l: Nay come daughter, stand at the bar of shame,
Either now quit thyself, or kill me ever:
Your marriage day is spoilt if all be true.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.l: A happy misery, whose my accuser?

sp.speaker: Physician
sp.l: I am that knows it true I speak,

lg.l: And I again too,
There's four that's enough I hope.
How can you witness sir that nothing know,
But what you have received from his report.
Must we not believe our physicians? pray you think
I know as much as every fool does.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: Let me be Trimtram: I pray you too sir.

lg.l: Sir if this bad man have laid a blemish
On my white name: he is a most false one,
Defaming me for the just denial
Of his soul lust, nay now you shall be known sir.
Sir I'm his sister and do better know him,
Than all of you give not too much belief
To his wild words, he's oftentimes mad sir.
Are you not mad to do this office,
Fie upon your malice.
I'll presently produce both nurse and child,
Whose very eyes shall call her mother, before it speaks.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, ha, by my troth I'd spend a shilling on that condition to hear that, I think in my conscience I shall take the physician in a lie if the child call her mother before it can speak, I'll never wrestle while I live again.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: It must be a she child if it do sir, and those speak the soonest of any living creatures they say.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: Baw waw, a dog will bark a month sooner, he's a very puppy else.

lg.l: Come tell truth twixt ourselves, here's none but friends
One spot a father's love will soon wipe off?
The truth and they try my love abundant,
I'll cover it with all the care I have ▪
And yet (Perhaps) make up a marriage day.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.l: Then it's true sir, I have child.

lg.l: Hast thou?
Well wipe thine eyes, I'm a grandfather then,
if all bastards were banished, the city would be thin,
In the thickest term time, well now let me alone
I'll try my wits for thee, Richard, Francis, Andrew,
None of my knaves within?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Here's one of 'em, sir, the guests come in apace.

sp.speaker: Russ.
sp.p: Do they Dick? let they have wine and sugar, we'll before they presently, but hark Dick.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: I long to hear this child speak i'faith, trim, I would this foolish physician would come once.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: If it calls her mother, I hope it shall never call you father.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: No, and it do I'll whip it i'faith, and give thee leave to whip me.

sp.speaker: Russ.
sp.l: Run on thy best legs Dick.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: I'll be here in a twinkling sir. Exit Ser.

div.stage: Enter physician, nurse, with the child.

sp.speaker: Physician
sp.p: Now gentlemen, believe your eyes, if not my tongue do not you call this your child?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Phew, that's not the point you promised us the child should call her mother, if it does this month, I'll ne'er go to the roaring school again.

sp.speaker: Nurse.
sp.l: Dis gentlemans, so he to me readen. Points to the physician.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Snails she's the physician's Bronstrops, trim.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: His fucus, his very tweke, i'faith.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: A glister in his teeth, let him take her with a purgation to him.

lg.l: 'Tis as your sister said: you are stark mad, sir,
This much confirms it, you have defamed
Mine honest daughter: I'll have you punished fort,
Besides the civil penance of your sin,
And keeping of your bastard.
This is fine,
All your wit and wealth must not thus carry it.

sp.speaker: Russ.
sp.l: Sir Chaugh a word with you.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: I'll not have her i'faith, sir, if Trimtram will have her and he will let him.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Who I, sir? I scorn it, if you'll have her, I'll have her too, I'll do as you do, and no otherwise.

lg.l: I do not meant to either, this only, sir,
That whatsoever you've seen, you would be silent,
Hinder not my child of another husband,
Though you forsake her.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.l: I'll not speak a word, i'faith,

lg.l: By these basket hilts, as I am a youth,
A gentleman a roarer.

sp.speaker: Russ.
sp.l: Charm your man I beseech you too.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: I warrant you sir he shall do nothing but what I do before him.

lg.l: I shall most dear thank you, o are you come,
Welcome son in law: this was beyond your hope,
We old men have pretty conceits sometimes,
Your wedding day's prepared, and this is it,
How think you of it?
As of the joyfull'st
That ever welcomed me, you show yourself now
A pattern to all kind fathers: my sweetest Jane,
Your captivity I meant but as sauce,
Unto your wedding dinner, now, I'm sure
'Tis far more welcome in this short restraint
Then had it freely come:

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: I have not the heart to see this gentleman gulled so, I will reveal, I make it mine own case 'tis a foul case.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: Remember you have sworn by your hilts.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: I'll break my hilts rather than conceal, I have a trick do thou follow me, I will reveal it, and yet not speak it neither.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: 'Tis my duty to follow you sir.

sp.speaker: Chaugh
sp.l: Sings.take heed in time o man unto thy head,

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: Sings.all is not gold that glistereth in bed.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.l: Look to't I say, thy bride's a Bronsterops,

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: And knows the thing that men wear in their slops,

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.l: A Hipocrene, a tweke, for and a fucus,

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: Let not fond love with foretops so rebuke us.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.l: Behold a baby of this maids begetting,

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: A deed of darkness after the sunset.

sp.speaker: Chau:
sp.l: I swear and sing thy bride has taken physic,

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: This was the doctor cured her of that phthisic.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.l: If you'll believe me I will say no more,

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: Thy brides a tweke as we do say that roar.

lg.l: Bear witness gentlemen I have not spoke a word,
My hilts are whole still.
This is a sweet epithalamium,
Unto the marriage bed, a musical
Harmonious Io: sir, you've wronged me,
And basely wronged me, was this your cunning fetch,
To fetch me out of prison, for ever
To marry me unto a strumpet?
None of those words good sir,
'Tis but a fault, and 'tis a sweet one too,
Come sir, your means is short, lengthen your fortunes,
With a fair proffer: I'll put a thousand pieces
Into the scale to help her to weigh it up,
Above the first dowry.
Ha? you say, well
Shame may be bought out at a dear rate,
A thousand pieces added to her dowry.
There's five hundred of they to make the bargain,
I have worthy guests coming and would not delude they,
Say: speak like a son to me.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.p: Your blessing sir, we are both yours, witness gentlemen these must be made up a thousand pieces, added to a first thousand for her dowry, to father that child,

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.l: For tother thousand I'll do't myself yet.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: Or I, if my master will.

lg.l: The bargain's made, sir, I have the tender
And possession both; and will keep my purchase,

sp.speaker: Chaw.
sp.p: Take her e'en to you with all her movables, I'll wear my bachelors buttons still.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: So will I i'faith; they are the best flowers in any man's garden, next to hearts-ease.

lg.l: This is as welcome as the other sir,
And both as the best bliss that ere on earth,
I shall enjoy, sir, this is mine own child,
You could not have found out a sitter father
Nor is it basely bred as you imagine
For we were wedded by the hand of heaven
Ere this work was begun.

sp.speaker: Chaw.
sp.l: At Pancridge, I'll lay my life on't,

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: I'll lay my life on't too, 'twas there,

lg.l: And that I must have revealed to you, sir,
Eat I had gone to church with this fair groom,
But thank this gentleman, he prevented me,
I am much bound unto your malice sir.
Now get you together for a couple of cunning ones,
But son, a word, the latter thousand pieces
Is now more than bargain.
No by my faith sir
Here's witness enough on't, must serve to pay my fees
Imprisonment is costly

sp.speaker: Chaw.
sp.p: By my troth the old man has guled himself, finely, well sir, I'll bid myself a guest, though not a groom, I'll dine and dance, and roar at the wedding for all this.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: So will I sir, if my master does,

lg.l: Well sir, you are welcome, but now, no more words on't,
Till we be set at dinner for there will mirth
Be the most useful for digestion,
See, my best guests are coming.

div.stage: Enter captain Ager, surgeon, lady Ager colonels sister, two friends.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Recovered sayest thou.

sp.speaker: Surgeon
sp.p: May I be excluded quite out of surgeons' hall else, marry I must tell you the wound was fain to be twice corroded, 'twas a plain gastrolophe, and a deep one, but I closed the lips on't with bandages and sutures, which is a kind conjunction of the parts separated against the course of nature.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Well sir, he is well

sp.speaker: Surgeon
sp.p: I feared him I assure you captain before the surture in the belly, it grew almost to a convulsion, and there was like to be a bloody issue from the hollow vessels of the kidneys.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: There's that, to thank thy news and thy art together.

sp.speaker: Surgeon
sp.p: And if your worship at any time stand in need of incision, if it be your fortune to light into my hands, I'll give you the best.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Uncle, the noble colonels recovered,

lg.l: Recovered.
Then honour is not dead in all parts cusse.

div.stage: Enter colonel with his too friends.

sp.p: Behold him yonder sir.

lg.l: My much unworthiness is now found out,
Thou'st not a face to fit it.
O lieutenant the wrong I have done his fame,
Puts me to silence, shame so confounds me,
That I dare not see him.
I never knew how poor my deserts were,
Till he appeared '; no way to give requital,
Here shame me lastingly; do't with his own,
Return this to him, tell him I have riches
In that abundance in his sister's love,
These come but to oppress me, and confound
All my deservings everlastingly:
I never shall requite my wealth in her say,
how soon from virtue and an honoured spirit,
May man receive what he may never merit.
This comes most happily, to express me better,
For since this will was made there fell to me
The manner of Fitz-dale, give 'em that too,
He's like to have charge there's fair hope
Of my sister's fruitfulness, for me
I never mean to change my mistress,
And war is able to maintain her servant,
Read there, a fair increase sir, by my faith,
He hath sent it back sir, with new additions.
How miserable he makes me, this enforces me
To break through all the passages of shame
And headlong fall,
You have a goodness
Has put me passed my answers, you may speak,
What you please now; I must be silent ever,
This day has shown me joys unvalued treasure,
I would not change this brotherhood with a monarch,
Into which blessed alliance sacred heaven
Ha's placed my kinsman, and given him his ends
Fair be that quarrel makes such happy friends.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
